SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 30 November 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) amended the Specifications and Standards for Foods, Food Additives, etc. to finalize the positive list of materials used in synthetic resins for food contact materials (FCM). As previously announced, the positive list system was enforced on 1 June 2020, and the transition period will end on 31 May 2025. 

3E Analysis :

The Specifications and Standards for Foods, Food Additives, etc. is one of the main regulations for FCM in Japan. The positive list system is applied to bases, additives, and coating agents used in resins. In principle, only materials listed in the positive list can be used in FCM.

After reviewing public opinion during the transition period, the MHLW amended the candidate positive lists and finalized them on 30 November 2023 in the MHLW Notification No. 324.

The finalized lists introduced five material groups, which are defined by factors such as glass transition temperature, ball pressure temperature, melting point temperature, polymer composition, etc., each with their specific use limit percentage.

Additionally, the MHLW removed the columns of the permitted food category because the appropriate usage methods vary by food. The ministry is planning to amend the Enforcement Rule on Food Sanitation Law Article 66-5 to require companies to manage these materials with proper usage methods.

The finalized positive lists consist of two tables.

Table 1 lists polymers of synthetic resins and their material groups. Although use limit percentages are not specified in Table 1, further specifications and restrictions are detailed separately in Circular No. 1130-1 of 2023 from the Food Standards and Evaluation Division, the Health Service and Environmental Health Bureau.

Table 2 outlines additives and their respective use limit percentages across material groups. The list also has a column of further restrictions, such as usage temperature and permitted food category, which are defined in Circular No. 1130-4 of 2023.

In addition to the finalized published positive lists, the reference lists, Table 1 and Table 2 (note that if you use these hyperlinks, an Excel sheet will automatically download to your computer), used for the previous candidate positive lists are important sources of information providing the English name and CAS RN of each material. However, these reference lists and the finalized positive list would have discrepancies.

As a note, materials not listed in the positive lists can still be used as notified in Circular No. 0501-6 of 2020 from the Environmental Health and Food Safety Council if they do not directly contact food and do not exceed the allowable migration volume, which is 0.01mg/kg. Similarly, the standards for equipment, packages, and containers by material, such as phenol, melamine, urea, and formaldehyde resins in the MHLW Notice No. 370 of 1959 amended through No. 381 on 4 December 2020, remain unaffected.  

Business Impact :

Companies involved in manufacturing, importing, or selling FCM in Japan are advised to thoroughly assess their products before the enforcement date. Ensuring compliance with the positive lists is crucial, as materials not included in these lists will not be authorized for import, use, or sale as FCM.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please get in touch with us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

The Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 178 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) inventory on 27 September 2023. These additions went into effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

For workers' safety, the ISHL's Paragraph 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and report their test results if such substances—intended for manufacture or import—are not listed as existing chemicals.

Paragraph 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires the MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 27 September 2023, the MHLW announced that 178 new chemical substances, with entry IDs from 30896 to 31073, were added to the ISHL inventory. The inventory provides ISHL number(s) and Japanese chemical names for each entry. 

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should check whether their substances are listed in the updated ISHL chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain if they are subject to toxicity testing and reporting requirements.

Please note that the provided link is valid only for a limited time due to its fee-based subscription to Japan's official gazette. For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

On 9 November 2023, the Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan established threshold values for substances that cause skin and eye damage following the amendment to the Cabinet Order on Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL Cabinet Order). The list of designated chemicals was initially published on 4 July 2023. The effective date of the amendment is 1 April 2025.

3E Analysis :

Previously, the MHLW Labor Standard Bureau issued Circular No. 0704-1 to publish the list of substances causing skin and eye damage (皮膚等障害化学物質). According to the Ministerial Ordinance on Industrial Safety and Health, Article 594-2(1), which will come into force on 1 April 2025, companies handling the listed substances must ensure that workers wear impermeable protections.

Initially, the MHLW did not provide specific threshold values. However, with the latest amendment to the circular, the MHLW has now established the threshold values for substances that cause skin and eye damage (note that using this link will automatically download an Excel file to your computer). If a substance is present in a preparation at a concentration below the threshold value, it is not considered a substance that causes skin and eye damage.

These threshold values are determined based on the threshold values for preparations containing substances requiring labeling and safety data sheets (SDSs), as outlined in MHLW Notice No. 304 of 2023, issued on 9 November 2023, as an amendment to the ISHL Cabinet Order.

For skin irritant hazardous substances, the threshold value is set at a fixed rate of 1%. While the threshold value for skin-absorbing hazardous substances is also 1% in principle, exceptions include a reduced threshold of 0.1% for substances classified as mutagenicity class 1 or carcinogenicity class 1, and a threshold of 0.3% for substances classified as reproductive toxicity class 1, in accordance with the Japanese government’s Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals classification results.

Business Impact :

Although there is no current legal requirement to specify substances that cause skin and eye damage on SDSs, the authority advises companies to display them on SDSs. Companies should start assessing their products impacted by these new threshold values before the enforcement on 1 April 2025. Please pay close attention to further notices from the MHLW.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

On 30 August 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced amendments to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) Cabinet Order and Ministerial Order, as well as the Ordinance on Prevention of Hazards Due to Specified Chemical Substances. The amendments mandate labels and safety data sheets (SDSs) for all Globally Harmonized System (GHS) classified hazardous chemicals. A part of the amendment took effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s MHLW has been making amendments to the ISHL and related regulations to shift workplace chemical management from a regulation-based to an industry-directed approach. The amendment mandates labels and SDSs for all GHS (JIS Z 7252) hazardous substances classified by 31 March 2021. This affects more than 2,000 chemical substances.

Currently, 674 chemicals require labels and SDSs per the ISHL Cabinet Order (Appendix Table 9).

This amendment reorganizes Table 9, identifying 33 groups, including alkylmercury and its compounds, antimony and its compounds, cobalt and its compounds, uranium and its compounds, and lead and its compounds, as substances requiring labels and SDSs. Threshold values, previously set by the ISHL Ministerial Ordinance, are to be omitted; they will be stipulated through separate notifications after public comments.

The authority’s response to the public comments clarifies that whether a substance is subject to label and SDS requirements or not is determined based on the substance name rather than how it is produced.

Furthermore, the amendments remove seven substances, such as flutolanil, aluminum oxide, and zinc stearate, and they are no longer subject to mandatory labeling and SDS, effective immediately.

Products containing deleted substances and other substances subject to labels and SDSs at or above thresholds must display labels and SDSs.

The addition of substances subject to labels and SDSs will occur in two batches:

  • By 1 April 2025: 649 substances, grace period until 31 March 2026
  • By 1 April 2026: 779 substances, grace period until 31 March 2027

It is noted that the previous amendment published in 2022 announced the addition of 234 substances starting from 1 April 2024.

Japan’s GHS-classified chemicals are published by the National Institute of Technology and Evaluation (NITE). The candidate list is published by the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, Japan (JNIOSH).

Business Impact :

Companies should assess their products impacted by this amendment and closely follow further notices from the MHLW and opportunities for public comments. Companies must prepare labels and SDSs for these newly added chemicals accordingly.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

Japan has designated seven substances as narcotics under the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act and Stimulant Drugs Control Law. Published on 30 August 2023, the new designations will take effect on 29 September 2023.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that the following seven substances and their salts are now classified as narcotics:

  • ADB-BUTINACA
  • Etonitazepyne, N-pyrrolidino etonitazene
  • Etazene, etodesnitazene
  • Protonitazene
  • 3-Methylmethcathinone, 3-MMC
  • α-PiHP, α-PHiP
  • 2-Methyl-AP-237

According to the MHLW, all seven substances were formerly classified as designated drugs under the Japanese Pharmaceutical Act. Their classification was revoked due to the new designation for tighter controls.

The MHLW does not provide the CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Companies dealing with any of the newly designated substances will be subject to requirements under the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act or Stimulant Drugs Control Law, such as obtaining licenses or designations as manufacturers, suppliers, importers, exporters, etc., after 29 September 2023.

If the URL of the source document is no longer valid, please contact us at Support@3Eco.com for a copy (PDF in Japanese).

Alert Summary :

On 31 August 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) added five substances to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, distribution, purchase, possession, and use of these substances except for medical practices. The amendment will come into force on 10 September 2023.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s Pharmaceutical Law defines designated substances as those with a high probability of stimulating or suppressing effects on the central nervous system or producing hallucinatory effects and could cause health and hygiene hazards when used in the human body. These substances are often moved to the narcotics list later on.

The MHLW added the following three substances and two substance groups to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care:

  • ADB-BINACA
  • FXE, Fluorexetamine
  • N-Butylbutylone
  • Substances in which a straight-chain alkyl group (with a carbon number ranging from 3 to 8) is attached to the third position of 6a,7,8,10a-tetrahydro-6,6,9-trimethyl-6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran-1-ol, and there are no additional substituents at the first, third, sixth, and ninth positions, except for these. This excludes narcotics and drugs regulated by the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act.
  • Substances in which a straight-chain alkyl group (with a carbon number ranging from 3 to 8) is attached to the third position of 6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydro-6,6,9-trimethyl-6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran-1-ol, and there are no additional substituents at the first, third, sixth, and ninth positions, except for these. This excludes narcotics and drugs regulated by the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act.

Please note that English names are provided by 3E. The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs or English names.

Business Impact :

Effective on 10 September 2023, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of any of the newly listed substances, other than for medical care, are banned. Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including fines and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Law.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

On 31 July 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) jointly published Notice No. 4, adding 179 chemical substances to the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL) inventory, known as the ENCS inventory. These substances have been designated as General Chemical Substances (一般化学物質). The notice entered into force immediately.

3E Analysis :

Pursuant to the Act on the Evaluation of Chemical Substances and Regulation of Their Manufacture, etc., commonly known as the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL), the ministries were notified that these substances manufactured in or imported into Japan are slated to be "new chemical substances." After a thorough evaluation, they are now designated as General Chemical Substances and added to the ENCS inventory.

Business Impact :

Substances that are not listed in the ENCS inventory are considered new chemical substances. Under the CSCL, manufacturers and/or importers of new chemical substances must submit a notification of the names and other information of the new chemical substances to the competent ministries (MHLW, METI, and MOE) prior to their manufacture in or import to Japan.

Manufacturers and importers of General Chemical Substances in the ENCS inventory in a quantity of one ton or more per year must submit an annual report of their actual manufactured and/or imported quantities for the previous year.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3eco.com.

Alert Summary :

On 26 July 2023, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Food and Drug Division, Food Safety Bureau published Notice No. 0726-1 to add calcium phytate to the Designated Food Additive List. The Designated Food Additive List is stipulated in Appendix 1 of the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. 

The update is effective immediately. 

3E Analysis :

Pursuant to Article 10 of the Food Sanitation Law, food additives designated by the Minister of Health, Labor, and Welfare are authorized to be sold, manufactured, imported, processed, used, stored, or displayed for sale. The designated food additives are subject to compliance with the Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc.

The MHLW adds potassium calcium phytate (フィチン酸カルシウム) to the Designated Food Additive List. Calcium phytate is allowed for use only in manufacturing grape wine, which is defined by Liquor Tax Law Article 3(13) and (14) and must not exceed 0.08 g per 1 L of grape wine. 

Business Impact :

The Designated Food Additive List in Appendix 1 of the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule is one of the positive food additive lists that Japanese authorities approve. Substances that are not listed may be subject to being banned from use in Japan and require a further approval process. 

Companies, furthermore, must consult the Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc. for detailed use and quantity requirements for those additives listed in the Designated Food Additive List.

Should the URLs of the source documents change, please contact us at Support@3eco.com for a copy (PDF in Japanese).

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 30 August 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced amendments to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) Cabinet Order and Ministerial Order, as well as the Ordinance on Prevention of Hazards Due to Specified Chemical Substances. The amendments mandate labels and safety data sheets (SDSs) for all Globally Harmonized System (GHS) classified hazardous chemicals. A part of the amendment took effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s MHLW has been making amendments to the ISHL and related regulations to shift workplace chemical management from a regulation-based to an industry-directed approach. The amendment mandates labels and SDSs for all GHS (JIS Z 7252) hazardous substances classified by 31 March 2021. This affects more than 2,000 chemical substances.

Currently, 674 chemicals require labels and SDSs per the ISHL Cabinet Order (Appendix Table 9).

This amendment reorganizes Table 9, identifying 33 groups, including alkylmercury and its compounds, antimony and its compounds, cobalt and its compounds, uranium and its compounds, and lead and its compounds, as substances requiring labels and SDSs. Threshold values, previously set by the ISHL Ministerial Ordinance, are to be omitted; they will be stipulated through separate notifications after public comments.

The authority’s response to the public comments clarifies that whether a substance is subject to label and SDS requirements or not is determined based on the substance name rather than how it is produced.

Furthermore, the amendments remove seven substances, such as flutolanil, aluminum oxide, and zinc stearate, and they are no longer subject to mandatory labeling and SDS, effective immediately.

Products containing deleted substances and other substances subject to labels and SDSs at or above thresholds must display labels and SDSs.

The addition of substances subject to labels and SDSs will occur in two batches:

  • By 1 April 2025: 649 substances, grace period until 31 March 2026
  • By 1 April 2026: 779 substances, grace period until 31 March 2027

It is noted that the previous amendment published in 2022 announced the addition of 234 substances starting from 1 April 2024.

Japan’s GHS-classified chemicals are published by the National Institute of Technology and Evaluation (NITE). The candidate list is published by the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, Japan (JNIOSH).

Business Impact :

Companies should assess their products impacted by this amendment and closely follow further notices from the MHLW and opportunities for public comments. Companies must prepare labels and SDSs for these newly added chemicals accordingly.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

The Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 148 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) inventory on 27 June 2023. These additions went into effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

For workers' safety, the ISHL's Clause 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and report their test results if such substances—intended for manufacture or import—are not listed as existing chemicals.

Clause 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires the MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 27 June 2023, the MHLW announced that 148 new chemical substances, with entry IDs from 30748 to 30895, were added to the ISHL inventory. The inventory provides ISHL number(s) and Japanese chemical names for each entry. 

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should check whether their substances are listed in the updated ISHL chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain if they are subject to toxicity testing and reporting requirements.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
This is a new list.

Please ensure that DB List Phrase and Short List Desc are copied from the boxes above.

 

NOTE 

Please capture columns A, B, E:G, I (this is the added date), J (effective date) and the note in cell 82-84.

Please note that with this new OEL, currently, there are three OEL and OEL-like standards that must be displayed on SDS.

This new OEL is the concentration standards (濃度基準), which is similar to the US Threshold Limit Value (TLV) which has Time-Weighted Average, Short-Term Exposure Limit, and Ceiling.

The MHLW explains that other OEL-like standards are not OEL for the following reasons:

1) JSOH OEL recommendations (JSOH, QSAP252) are not legally binding measures

2) ISHL Workplace Managerial Concentration Standard (管理濃度, JP_TLV, QSAP248) is used to determine workplace environment class, and if the workplace is classified as type 3 managerial class (第三管理区分), company must take measures to improved the workplace to be re-classified as type 1 or 2 (Specified Chemical rule 36-3 etc). It does not prohibit exceeding the limit per se. On the other hand, this new OEL MUST NOT BE EXCEEDED. In this regard, Managerial Concentration Stadard is applied to ambient concentration of the workplace, but the new OEL is applied to workers' exposure levels. Thus, if workers wear proper RPE which have protective factor higher than the necessary standard,  the regulatory requirement is fulfilled. (See the MHLW study paper 濃度基準に関する文献レビュー等 for details)
SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 27 April 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced an amendment to the Ordinance on Industrial Safety and Health. The amendment sets the exposure limits for 67 chemicals that do not pose health risks by limiting exposures among the substances that require risk assessments. The amendment will enter into effect on 1 April 2024.

3E Analysis :

According to the Ordinance on Industrial Safety and Health (労働安全衛生法) Article 577(2)(2), companies must limit exposure to chemical substances in indoor workplaces at or below the exposure limits.

The amendment and the new technical guideline, also announced on 27 April 2023, together set exposure limits (厚生労働大臣が定める濃度の基準) for 67 chemical substances among those that require risk assessments and safety data sheets (SDSs).

Unlike the exposure limits (管理濃度) under the ISHL Article 65(2)(2) that are based on an evaluation of the working environment where the designated chemicals are handled, the newly set exposure limits (濃度基準値) in this amendment are meant to limit exposure to the listed chemicals regardless of the working environment.

The following two exposure limits are introduced:

  • Eight-hour exposure limit: A time-weighted average value of the concentration of the listed substance in an eight-hour exposure (8-hour time-weighted average value) must not exceed this limit.
  • Short-time exposure limit: A time-weighted average value of the concentration of the listed substance for 15 minutes of exposure at the highest concentration level (15-minute time-weighted average value) must not exceed this limit.

If the 15-minute time-weighted value exceeds the 8-hour concentration limit but is at or below the short-time concentration limit, the maximum exposure to the listed substance should not exceed four times a day with one-hour intervals between exposures.

For those without short-time concentration limits, the 15-minute time-weighted average value should not exceed three times the eight-hour exposure limit in any exposure setting.

The exposure limits for acrolein, glutaraldehyde, chloropicrin, and 2-butenal, among the listed substances, are the maximum ceiling concentration, and therefore, exposure to such chemicals must not exceed the short-time exposure limit.

The authority did not set exposure limits for chemicals with known carcinogenicity due to the difficulty in setting a clear threshold, but companies must limit exposure to such substances as much as possible.

Business Impact :

Companies must conduct workplace risk assessments, measure exposure levels, and ensure that workers are not exposed to the listed chemical substances exceeding the exposure limits. The exposure limit of the listed chemical substances must be displayed in section 8 on the SDS.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

On 21 June 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) added three substances to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, distribution, purchase, possession, and use of these substances except for medical practices. The amendment will be effective on 1 July 2023.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s Pharmaceutical Law defines designated substances as those with a high probability of stimulating or suppressing effects on the central nervous system or producing hallucinatory effects and could cause health and hygiene hazards when used in the human body. These substances are often moved to the narcotics list later on.

The following three substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care:

  • EN: N-(1-Adamantyl)-1-(4-fluorobutyl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide 
    • Other names: 4F-ABINACA, 4F-ABUTINACA
    • JP: N－（１－アダマンチル）－１－（４―フルオロブチル） －１Ｈ－インダゾ－ル－３－カルボキサミド
  • EN: 2-(4-Ethoxybenzyl)-5-nitro-1-[2-(piperidiN-1-yl)ethyl]-benzimidazole
    • Other names: N-Piperidinyl Etonitazene, Etonitazepipne
    • JP: ２－（４－エトキシベンジル）－５－ニトロ－１－［２－ （ピペリジン－１－イル）エチル］ベンズイミダゾール
  • EN: 2-(3-Chlorophenyl)-3-methylmorpholine
    • Other names: 3-CPM, 3-Chlorophenmetrazin
    • JP: ２－（３－クロロフェニル）－３－メチルモルフォリン

Please not that English names are provided by 3E. The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs or English names.

Business Impact :

Effective on 1 July 2023, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of any of the newly listed substances, other than for medical care, are banned.

Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including fines and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Law.

Alert Summary :

On 26 May 2023, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced the addition of 3-aminopropane-1-ol to the list of designated substances under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substances Control Law (PDSCL). This amendment will come into effect on 1 June 2023.

Additionally, the MHLW removed diantimony tetraoxide and 2-isobutoxyethanol from the list, with the removal of these two substances taking immediate effect.

3E Analysis :

Under Japan’s PDSCL, manufacturers, importers, and sellers of designated substances are required to adhere to various regulations, including business registration, labeling, and documentation of transfer records. In addition, they must adhere to measures to prevent theft, loss, leakage, and proper storage, disposal, and transportation of these substances.

The PDSCL designates substances with acute toxicity and pose risks to human health as either poisonous or deleterious substances.

The latest amendment brings the following changes:

Additions (effective from 1 June 2023):

  • 3-Aminopropane-1-ol (CAS RN 156-87-6) and formulations containing it at concentrations exceeding 1%

Removals (effective from 26 May 2023):

  • Diantimony tetraoxide (CAS RN 1332-81-6) and formulations containing it
  • 2-Isobutoxyethanol (CAS RN 4439-24-1) and formulations containing it at concentrations exceeding 15%

Those who currently manufacture, import, or sell the newly designated substance are required to comply with the following requirements beginning 31 August 2023:

  • Prohibition of handling other than registered business (Article 3)
  • Placement of poisonous and deleterious substance handlers (Article 7)
  • Alteration of registration (Article 9)

Furthermore, if the newly designated substance is already manufactured, imported, or sold by 1 June 2023, labeling and safety data sheets (SDS) will not be required until 31 August 2023.

Business Impact :

Companies that are currently involved in the manufacturing, importing, or selling of the substances newly designated or removed should review their labels and SDS and other relevant requirements, such as business registration and proper storage and transportation standards.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 31 March 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), and Ministry of Environment (MOE) announced that they updated the Notification for the Exempt General Chemical List based on the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL). The update went into effect immediately. 

3E Analysis :

Article 8, Section 1-3 of the CSCL stipulates that the MHLW, METI, and MOE release the Notification for Exempt General Chemical List, which contains substances that are not designated as Class 1 or Class 2 specified chemical substances or monitoring chemicals, nor as priority assessment chemicals (PAC).

No annual reporting is required this year for the manufacture or import of the listed chemical substances that are exempt.

Business Impact :

After the amendment is implemented, companies that manufacture or import more than one ton of the exempt chemical substances will no longer need to notify the quantity and the use category to the METI. 

If the URL of the source document is no longer valid, please contact us at Support@3Eco.com for a copy (PDF in Japanese).

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

The Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 129 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) inventory on 27 March 2023. These additions went into effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

For workers' safety, the ISHL's Clause 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and report their test results if such substances—intended for manufacture or import—are not listed as existing chemicals.

Clause 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires the MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 27 March 2023, the MHLW announced that 129 new chemical substances, with entry IDs from 30619 to 30747, were added to the ISHL inventory. The inventory provides ISHL number(s) and Japanese chemical names for each entry. 

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should check whether their substances are listed in the updated ISHL chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain if they are subject to toxicity testing and reporting requirements.

Please note that the provided link is valid only for a limited time due to its fee-based subscription to Japan's official gazette. For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 10 March 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) added seven substances to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, distribution, purchase, possession, and use of these substances except for medical practices. The amendment will be effective on 19 March 2023.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s Pharmaceutical Law defines designated substances as those with a high probability of stimulating or suppressing effects on the central nervous system or hallucinatory effects and could cause health and hygiene hazards when used in the human body. These substances are often moved to the narcotics list later on.

The following five substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care:

  • N-ethyl-N-methyltryptamine and its salts
  • N,N-diethyl-7-methyl-4-pentanoyl-4,6,6a,7,8,9-hexahydroindolo[4,3-fg]quinoline-9-carboxamide and its salts
  • 6a,7,8,10a-tetrahydro-6,6,9-trimethyl-3-pentyl-6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran-1-yl acetate and its salts
  • 6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydro-6,6,9-trimethyl-3-pentyl-6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran-1-yl acetate and its salts
  • N-(4-fluorophenyl)-N-(1-phenethylpiperidin-4-yl)furan-2-carboxamide and its salts
  • 6a,7,8,9,10,10a-Hexahydro-6,6,9-trimethyl-3-pentyl-6H-dibenzo[b,d]pyran-1-yl acetate and its salts
  • 1-[1-(3-methylphenyl)cyclohexyl]pyrrolidine and its salts

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Effective on 19 March 2023, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of any of the newly listed substances, other than for medical care, are banned.

Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including fines and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Law.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 31 March 2023, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) deleted six substances from the list of priority assessment chemical substances (PACS) under the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL). Also on 1 April 2023, Japan published a list of six substances that were added as PACS. The lists became effective upon publication.

3E Analysis :

PACS are substances designated by the MHLW, METI, and MOE for priority chemical assessment due to their potential risk for long-term toxicity to human health, fauna, and flora in the living environment. 

The following substances are among those that were deleted:

  • Chlorodifluoromethane (MITI No. (2)-93)
  • Methyl dodecanoate (MITI No. (2)-798)

The following substances are among those that were added:

  • Sodium trihydrogen 2,2',2'',2'''-(ethane-1,2-diyldinitrilo)tetraacetate (MITI No. (2)-1265)
  • Alpha,alpha'-[(Alkyl(C=8-18, normal chain)azanediyl)bis(ethane-2,1-diyl(or methylethane-2,1-diyl))]bis{omega-hydroxypoly[oxyethane-1,2-diyl/oxy(methylethane-1,2-diyl)]} (The number of repetitions of the repeating unit is 1 or more.) (It is limited to those of an average molecular weight of less than 1,000.) (MITI No. (7)-60)

No CAS RNs were provided by the ministries.

Business Impact :

Under the CSCL, companies manufacturing or importing 1 ton or more of PAC substances must submit their previous year’s annual volume report by 30 June 2023 (paper submission) or 31 July 2023 (by e-Gov submission).

The six substances newly added to PAC on 1 April 2023 must be reported as general chemical substances in the Japanese FY 2023 (1 April 2023 to 31 March 2024) for the FY 2022 (1 April 2022 to 31 March 2023) report, but as PAC in FY 2024 for the FY 2023 report.

The six substances deleted from PAC on 1 April 2023 must be reported as PAC in FY 2023 for the FY 2022 report, but as general chemicals in FY 2024 for the FY 2023 report.

If the URL of the source document is no longer valid, please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 23 December 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Environment (MOE) added four substances, including perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS), perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), and their salts to the list of designated substances of the Water Pollution Control Act. The amendment will be effective on 2 February 2023.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s Water Pollution Control Act aims to protect human health and the living environment from water pollution released from plants and factories. When violated, the law requires corporations to pay compensation for damages.

This amendment added PFOS, PFOA, and their salts. However, those included in foam extinguishing agents are excluded when they are used to deal with accidents in the designated workplace that handles designated substances. However, Japan continues to encourage corporations to replace foam extinguishers with non-PFOS type chemicals.

The law previously defined 56 substances as designated substances that pose risks to human health and the living environment when a considerable amount is released into public water.

The following four substances were added to the list of designated substances:

  • Aniline
  • PFOA and its salts
  • Perfluoro(octane-1-sulfonic acid) and its salts
  • Linear alkylbenzenesulfonic acid and its salts

The MOE did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 26 December 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that approximately 120 carcinogens that are among those listed on the safety data sheet (SDS) chemical list would require 30 years of record-keeping. Those carcinogens that were classified based on JIS: Z7252 (GHS classification Carcinogens Class 1A and 1B) by 31 March 2021 will be subject to this record-keeping responsibility starting on 1 April 2023.

3E Analysis :

The MHLW previously announced the amendment of the ISHL, which mandates that companies that manufacture or handle the 674 substances that are on the SDS chemical list to conduct workplace risk assessments and take protective measures to lower exposures to harmful substances. The amendment establishes two effective dates, depending on the substance: 1 April 2023 and 1 April 2024.

According to ISHL Enforcement Rule Article 577 (2), approximately 120 carcinogens among the substances listed on the SDS chemical list have been selected for the 30-year record-keeping obligation. Carcinogen names and their CAS RNs are available in Japanese on the MHLW website.

Furthermore, companies may refer to the specific cut-off values per substance on the SDS chemical list in order to determine applicability for the record-keeping obligation.

Please note this carcinogen list is separate from the carcinogenic substances defined by the ISHL Act Article 28-3 that recommends 30 years of record-keeping.

Business Impact :

From 1 April 2023, companies that manufacture and handle the listed carcinogens must keep management and health-evaluation records for 30 years. Substances handled temporarily, defined as those that workers are not exposed to continuously, are exempt from this record-keeping duty.

Additionally, the provided carcinogen tables contain 80 carcinogens that require record-keeping, effective from 1 April 2024. Companies are encouraged to prepare for the upcoming duties accordingly.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 12 December 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) published an amendment to the Japanese Pharmacopoeia 18th Edition (JP18), which was originally published on 6 June 2021.

3E Analysis :

Pursuant to Article 41 of the Act on Securing Quality, Efficacy, and Safety of Products Including Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices, the MHLW publishes the Japanese Pharmacopoeia every five years and amendments when necessary to ensure the quality of pharmaceuticals, as well as testing methods.

JP18 contains 2,042 pharmaceuticals, including chemical and herbal medicines, and the number of pharmaceuticals has increased with each new edition. JP18 is available in English, but the amendment is available only in Japanese (English names of pharmaceuticals A-L and M-Z are provided with CAS RNs).

The Pharmaceutical Affairs and Food Sanitation Council (PAFS), under the MHLW, evaluates new drugs and/or pharmaceuticals widely used in the U.S. and EU to add them to the JP immediately after evaluation for generic drug approval.

By listing pharmaceuticals and testing methods that are particularly important for public health, the MHLW aims to ensure that generics, which are primarily manufactured outside of Japan, and brand-name drugs are manufactured under equivalent quality standards.

The listed pharmaceuticals and testing methods must comply with the quality standard stipulated in JP18 starting on 1 July 2024.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers of generic drugs need to pay attention to JP18 because the pharmaceuticals listed in it whose properties (i.e., physical and chemical characteristics of a compound) and quality do not comply with the JP18 standards must not be sold, distributed, and therefore, must not be manufactured, imported, stored, or displayed for sale or distribution.

The JP19 is planned for publication in April 2026, but another amendment of the JP18 will likely be published before that.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 7 December 2022, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced the designation of 33 chemical substances as mutagens under the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL). The manufacture and handling of these mutagens, including products containing such substances in a concentration over 1% by weight, are subject to health and safety measures to protect workers at the workplace.

3E Analysis :

From the list of new chemical substances under ISHL, 33 substances were identified as mutagenns, including the following examples:

  • Reaction products of 2-acetyl-1-aminoanthracene-9,10-dione and 4-methylbenzene-1-sulfonamide, which consists of N-(3-acetyl-4-amino-9,10-dioxo-9,10-dihydroanthracen-1-yl)-4-methylbenzene-1-sulfonamide as a major component
  • 2-Ethyl-1-nitroanthracene-9,10-dione
  • 2-[(2R)-Oxan-2-yl]ethyl 4-nitrobenzene-1-sulfonate

When manufacturing or handling these substances, including products containing the substances in a concentration over 1% by weight, health and safety measures must be implemented in accordance with the "Guidelines to Prevent Health Hazards Caused by Chemical Substances with Recognized Strong Mutagenicity" (Tsuyoi hen-i gensē ga mitomerareta kagaku busshitsu ni yoru kenkō higai wo bōshi surutame no shishin) of 17 May 1993. The necessary measures include:

  • Preventative measures for worker exposure (e.g., use of proper personal protective equipment (PPE) and ventilation systems)
  • Work environment monitoring and evaluation
  • Occupational health training
  • Use of the globally harmonized system (GHS) of classification and labeling and safety data sheets (SDS)
  • Relevant record-keeping

No CAS RNs were provided.

Business Impact :

Companies should check their chemical inventories to see if any of their facilities manufacture or handle these newly designated mutagens and their mixtures with concentrations over 1% by weight. If that is the case, companies must take necessary measures following the guidelines to protect their workers from health hazards. In addition, manufacturers, sellers, or importers of the affected chemical substances must ensure their strong mutagenicity is indicated on the label or SDS.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

On 16 December 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) added five substances to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, distribution, purchase, possession, and use of these substances except for medical practices. The amendment will be effective on 26 December 2022.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s Pharmaceutical Law defines designated substances as those with a high probability of stimulating or suppressing effects on the central nervous system or hallucinatory effects and could cause health and hygiene hazards when used in the human body. These substances are often moved to the narcotics list later on.

The following five substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care:

  • N-(1-amino-1-oxo-3-phenylpropan-2-yl)-1-butyl-1H-indazol-3-carboxamide and its salts
  • N-(1-amino-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)-1-hexyl-1H-1H-indazol-3-carboxamide and its salts
  • 2-(Isopropylamino)-2-(3-methoxyphenyl)cyclohexanone and its salts
  • 1-(2-Diethylamino)ethyl-2-(4-ethoxybenzyl)benzimidazole and its salts
  • N-methyl-1-(5-methylthiophen-2-yl)propan-2-amine and its salts

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Effective on 26 December 2022, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of any of the newly listed substances, other than for medical care, are banned.

Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including fines and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Law.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3Eco.com.

Alert Summary :

The Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 172 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) inventory on 27 September 2022. These additions went into effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

For the purpose of workers' safety, the ISHL's Clause 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and report their test results if such substances—intended for manufacture or import—are not listed as existing chemicals.

Clause 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires the MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 27 September 2022, the MHLW announced that 172 new chemical substances, with entry IDs from 30266 to 30437, were added to the ISHL inventory. The inventory provides ISHL number(s) and Japanese chemical names for each entry. 

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should check whether their substances are listed in the updated ISHL chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain if they are subject to toxicity testing and reporting requirements. 

Please note that the provided link is valid only for a limited time due to its fee-based subscription to Japan's official gazette. For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 26 October 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) published Notice No. 318 to add calcium L-tartrate and potassium ferrocyanide to the usage standards as additives permitted for use in grape liquors.

3E Analysis :

The major changes promulgated by Notice No. 318 include the addition of calcium L-tartrate with an allowed quantity of 2.0 g or less per 1 L of grape liquor. Calcium L-tartrate must not be used in food other than grape liquor.

Another change includes a new use restriction for potassium ferrocyanide. Previously, the additive was used only for salt. With this amendment, it is now allowed for use in grape liquor as well. The additive must not exceed 0.001 g as a form of anhydrous potassium ferrocyanide per 1 L of grape liquor.

Business Impact :

Under this newly added restriction, manufacturers of grape liquors will be allowed to use a limited amount of calcium L-tartrate and potassium ferrocyanide.

This change happened as a result of the previously held evaluation by the Food Safety Commission of Japan that evaluated the two additives based on their effectiveness, safety, and usage in foreign countries.

Please note that the provided link is valid only for a limited time due to its fee-based subscription to Japan's official gazette. For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@3eco.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Japan Newly Adds Potassium Hydrogen Carbonate to Designated Food Additives List

Alert Summary

On 30 August 2022, Japan MHLW (Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare) Food and Drug Division Food Safety Bureau Notices No. 0830-2 was published to add potassium hydrogen carbonate to the Designated Food Additive List. The Designated Food Additive List is stipulated in Appendix 1 of Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. 

The update is effective immediately. 

3E Analysis

Pursuant to Article 10 of the Food Sanitation Law, food additives designated by the Minister of Health, Labor and Welfare are authorized to be sold, manufactured, imported, processed, used, stored or displayed for sale. The designated food additives are subject to compliance with the Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc.

MHLW newly adds potassium hydrogen carbonate (炭酸水素カリウム) to the Designated Food Additive List. The authority provides GMP (Good Manufacturing Practice) for the use of potassium hydrogen carbonate, which means industry is expected to determine the quantities that are adequate for food. Additionally, potassium hydrogen carbonate may be used to manufacture fruit wine that is defined by Liquor Tax Law Art. 3(13) and (14). 

Business Impact

The Designated Food Additive List in Appendix 1 of Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule is one of the positive food additive lists that Japanese authority approves. Substances that are not listed in the list may be subject to ban for use in Japan and require further approval process. 

Companies, furthermore, must consult with Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc. for detail use and quantity requirements for those additives listed in Designated Food Additive List.

Should the URLs of the source documents are no longer valid, please contact us at Support@3eco.com for a copy (PDF, in Japanese).

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Summary

On 29 July 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW); Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI); and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) jointly published Notice No. 4, adding 185 chemical substances to the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL) inventory. These substances have been designated as General Chemical Substances (一般化学物質), effective 29 July 2022. 

Review

Pursuant to the Act on the Evaluation of Chemical Substances and Regulation of Their Manufacture, etc., commonly known as the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL), the ministries were notified that these substances are slated for new manufacture in or import to Japan (i.e., new chemical substances). After evaluation, they are now designated as General Chemical Substances and added to the CSCL inventory. 

Analysis

Substances that are not listed in the CSCL inventory are considered as new chemical substances. Under the CSCL, manufacturers and/or importers of new chemical substances must submit a notification of the names and other information of the new chemical substances to the competent ministries (i.e., MHLW, METI, and MOE) prior to their manufacture in or import to Japan. 

Manufacturers and importers of General Chemical Substances in the CSCL inventory in a quantity of one ton or more per year must submit an annual report of their actual manufactured and/or imported quantities for the previous year.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 7 March 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that six substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of these substances other than for the purpose of medical care. The amendment went into effect 10 days after the announcement.

3E Analysis :

Under Japan's Pharmaceutical Law, designated pharmaceuticals are chemical substances that are allowed to be used for preventive medical care, medical diagnosis, and medical practice when the purpose has been proven to cause a low risk of harm and danger to the human body.

The following substances are included in the six added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care:

  • Ethyl 2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamido]-3,3-dimethylbutanoate and its salts
  • 1,2-Diphenyl-2-(pyrrolidin-1-yl)ethanone and its salts

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Since the substances are now listed as designated drugs, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of the substances, other than for the purpose of medical care, are banned.

Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including fines and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Law.

Please note that the source link may not work. For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese), please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

Alert Summary :

On 31 March 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), and Ministry of Environment (MOE) announced that they updated the Notification for Exempt General Chemical List based on the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL). The update went into effect immediately. 

3E Analysis :

Article 8, Section 1-3 of the CSCL stipulates that the MHLW, METI, and MOE release the Notification for Exempt General Chemical List, which contains substances that are not designated as Class 1 or Class 2 specified chemical substances or monitoring chemicals, nor as priority assessment chemicals (PAC).

No annual reporting is required this year for the manufacture or import of the listed chemical substances that are exempt.

Business Impact :

After the amendment is implemented, companies that manufacture or import more than one ton of the exempt chemical substances will no longer need to notify the quantity and the use category to the METI.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 31 March 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) published a list of 13 chemical substances that have been deleted as priority assessment chemical substances (PACS) under the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL). The next day, 1 April 2022, they published a list of four chemical substances that have been added as PACS under the CSCL. The lists became effective upon publication.

3E Analysis :

PACS are substances designated by the MHLW, METI, and MOE for priority chemical assessment due to their potential risk for long-term toxicity to human health, fauna, and flora in the living environment. 

The following substances are among those that were deleted:

  • 1,2-Epoxybutane
  • 0-Chloroaniline

The following substances are among those that were added:

  • Diazenedicarboxamide
  • Methyl-(1H-1,3-benzimidazole-2-yl) carbamate

No CAS RNs were provided by the ministries.

Business Impact :

Companies must submit an annual report about the manufacture and import of the PACS that are added under the CSCL in the Japanese fiscal year 2022 (April 2022 to March 2023) by the end of June 2023.

As to the manufacture and import of the five PACS that were deleted from the CSCL in the Japanese fiscal year 2021 (April 2021 to March 2022), companies should still submit a report about them as general chemical substances by the end of June 2022.

If the URL of the source document is no longer valid, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com for a copy (PDF in Japanese).

Alert Summary :

The Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 208 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) inventory on 25 March 2022. These additions went into effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

For the purpose of workers' safety, ISHL's Clause 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and to report their test results if such substances—intended for manufacture or import—are not listed as existing chemicals.

Clause 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires the MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 25 March 2022, the MHLW announced 208 new chemical substances, including:

  • Zinc biz (diethylphosphinate)
  • 2-amino-3-(benzyloxy)-6-bromophenol

The MHLW provided no CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should check whether their substances are listed on the updated ISHL chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain if they are subject to toxicity testing and reporting requirements. 

If the link to the source document has expired, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com for a copy (PDF in Japanese).

Alert Summary :

On 24 February 2022, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced the addition of 234 substances to Table 9 of the Cabinet Order of the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL Cabinet Order) and relevant cut-off values to Table 2 of the Ministerial Order of the ISHL (ISHL Ministerial Order).

Both tables will enter into force on 1 April 2024. 

3E Analysis :

Article 57 of the ISHL requires any importer or manufacturer to put labels on containers and packaging for any hazardous substance designated in Table 9 of the ISHL Cabinet Order. In addition, Article 57-2 requires the safety data sheet (SDS) to be provided.

In addition, Table 2 of the ISHL Ministerial Order contains a list of substances, which is derived from Table 9 of the ISHL Cabinet Order, with specific SDS and label cut-off values assigned to each of the listed substances.

According to Japanese Industrial Standard JIS Z 7253-2019, it is mandatory to show these ISHL lists in section 15 of the Japanese SDS together with the name of the listed chemical substance exceeding the stated cut-off values.

In December 2021, the MHLW made an announcement that they were planning to add these lists of chemicals in the next five years. This is the first promulgation of the planned series of additions.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers or importers should be aware of the significant additions to the list of hazardous substances as well as their labeling, SDS, and risk assessment requirements.

The labeling obligation for the volume of substances, which was newly added to Table 9 and will enter into effect on 1 April 2024, has a grace period until 1 April 2025. However, according to the notice by the MHLW on 11 January 2022, companies are "obligated to make effort" to indicate these newly added substances on SDSs during transitional periods.

For a copy of the source document (PDF in Japanese) if the link does not work, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 28 January 2022, the Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced revisions to the lists under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substances Designation Order. 

The effective date will be 1 February 2022 in principle, but each substance has a different effective date and transitional period.

3E Analysis :

The following substance is moved from the poisonous list to the deleterious list:

  • Preparation containing 0.1% or less of sodium [2-(carboxylatophenyl)thio]-ethyl-mercury

The concentration limit of 0.5%–1.5% for the following substance is changed from poisonous to deleterious:

  • 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-4-methylbenzyl (Z)-3-(2-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoro-1-propenyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate

The effective date for these changes will be 1 February 2022. The "poisonous" label on these substances will last until 30 April 2022.

In addition, the following substance is deleted from the list of deleterious substances:

  • Preparation containing 1,2-Di(2-{4-[2-(2-methylpropoxy)carbonyl-2-cyanoethenyl]phenylthio}ethoxy) ethane. The effective date for this substance is 28 January 2022.

Finally, the following substance is added to the list of deleterious substances:

  • Preparation containing 4-methylbenzenesulfonic acid; however, a preparation containing 5% or less of this substance is exempt. The effective date for this substance will be 1 February 2022. The volume of this substance that already exists on 1 February 2022 is exempt from the obligation to use the deleterious label until 30 April 2022.

Business Impact :

Companies dealing with these substances will be subject to the requirements under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substances Control Act as of 1 February 2022. However, the amendments offer affected businesses an interim period to comply with certain requirements (e.g., business registration for manufacture, import, or sale and the appointment of qualified personnel for handling poisonous and deleterious substances and proper labeling) until 30 April 2022.

For a copy of the source documents (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 19 January 2022, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that three substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of these substances other than for the purpose of medical care. The amendment went into effect 10 days after the announcement.

3E Analysis :

Under Japan's Pharmaceutical Law, designated pharmaceuticals are chemical substances that are allowed to be used for preventive medical care, medical diagnosis, and medical practice when the purpose has been proven to cause a low risk of harm and danger to the human body.

The following three substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care:

  • 5-(cyclohexylmethyl)-2-(2-phenylpropan-2-yl) -2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrido [4,3-b] indole-1-one and its salts
  • 1-{1-[1-(4-bromophenyl) ethyl] piperidine-4-yl}-1,3-dihydro-2H-benzo [d] imidazole-2-one and its salts
  • Methyl-2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-pyrrolo [2,3-b] pyridine-3-carboxamide]-3,2-dimethylbutanoate and its salts

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Since the substances are now listed as designated drugs, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of the substances, other than for the purpose of medical care, are banned.

Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including fines and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Law.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

The Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 196 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) inventory on 27 December 2021. These additions are effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

For the purpose of workers' safety, ISHL's Clause 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and to report their test results if such substances—intended for manufacture or import—are not listed as existing chemicals.

Clause 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 27 December 2021, MHLW announced 196 new chemical substances, including:

  • 2-acetyl-1-aminoanthracene-9, 10- dione;
  • (aminooxyacetic) acid;
  • 2-acetamide-2-deoxy-D- mannopyranose- water (1/1); etc. 

The MHLW provided no CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should check whether their substance is listed on the updated ISHL chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain if they are subject to toxicity testing and reporting requirements or not. 

If the link to the source document has expired, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com for a copy (PDF, in Japanese).

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 25 November 2021, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced the designation of 17 chemical substances as mutagens under the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL). The manufacture and handling of these mutagens, including products containing the substances in a concentration of 1% and above by weight, are subject to health and safety measures to protect workers at the workplace.

3E Analysis :

From the list of existing and new chemical substances under ISHL, 17 substances were identified, including the following examples:

  • 2-chloro-5-nitroaniline
  • 2-bromo-4-fluoro-1-nitro-3-(trifluoromethyl)benzene
  • 2,2'-(butan-1,4-diyl)bis(oxirane)

When manufacturing or handling these substances, including products containing the substances in a concentration of 1% and above by weight, health and safety measures must be implemented in accordance with the Guidelines to Prevent Health Hazards Caused by Chemical Substances with Recognized Strong Mutagenicity (強い変異原性が認められた化学物質による健康障害を防止するための指針) of 17 May 1993. The necessary measures include:

  • Preventative measures for worker exposure (e.g., use of proper personal protective equipment (PPE) and ventilation systems)
  • Work environment monitoring and evaluation
  • Occupational health training
  • Use of the globally harmonized system (GHS) of classification and labeling and safety data sheets (SDS)
  • Relevant record-keeping

No CAS RNs were provided.

Business Impact :

Companies should check their chemical inventories to see if any of the newly designated mutagens and their products containing the substances in a concentration of 1% and above by weight are manufactured or handled. If that is the case, companies must take necessary measures in accordance with the guidelines to protect their workers from health hazards. In addition, manufacturers, sellers, or importers of the affected chemical substances must make sure that their strong mutagenicity is indicated on the label or SDS.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese) if the link does not work, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

The Ministry of Environment of Japan (MOE) and other authorities updated the substance lists for the pollutant release and transfer register (PRTR) and safety data sheet (SDS) on 20 October 2021.

The updated lists will become effective on 1 April 2023.

The deadline for registration is on 30 June each year. This updated list will apply to the registration for the year 2024. The current list will be good for the registration to be made for the year 2023. 

3E Analysis :

The Law Concerning Reporting, etc. of Releases to the Environment of Specific Chemical Substances and Promoting Improvements in Their Management (PRTR Law) requires affected businesses to quantify the volumes of the chemical substances that they release to the environment or transfer in waste and report these volumes to the national government.

The cabinet order for the PRTR Law includes the lists of Class I, Specified Class I, and Class II designated chemical substances. 

As data has accumulated, test methods have developed, and international regulatory trends have shifted over time, those lists have been updated, and they will continue to be updated.

The MOE proposed the following changes to the lists on 4 December 2020, and finally promulgated them on 20 October 2021:

  • Class I: from 462 (current) to 515 substances
  • Specified Class I: from 15 (current) to 23 substances
  • Class II: from 100 (current) to 134 substances

The conditions mandated for businesses for the PRTR or SDS (volume, etc.) have not changed. It is advisable, however, to note that the definitions of "average molecular weight" and "weight percent" are added.

Business Impact :

Businesses should be aware of the changes to the lists for the PRTR and SDS.

Until the effective date of 1 April 2023, both current and new PRTR information should be printed on the Japanese SDS per the Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry.

If the URLs of the source documents are no longer valid, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com for a copy (PDF, in Japanese).

The transition symbols in the list are as follows.
　●: Excluded substances (2008 type 1: 86 substances, 2008 type 2: 78 substances)
　● (Grouping, etc., reason): Substances to which a new control number is assigned, such as grouping, expansion of scope, etc. (9) Substances)

　■: 2008 2nd class → 2021 1st class (12 substances)
　□: 1 specific class added (9 substances)                                                                                         
　★: Grouping of currently designated substances , New substances due to expansion of range, separation, etc. (7 substances)                                                                                    
　○: Newly added substances (2021 type 1: 188 substances, 2021 type 2: 68 substances, of which the substance revived at the time of enactment (partially expanded): 13 substances )
　◇: Name change (No change in specified range: Normal deletion, urea → urea change, unification of hydrocarbon chain notation)
 

In the column of "2021 (R3) revised government ordinance number" in the list, for the substance (class 1 designated chemical substance) in the attached table 1 of the revised government ordinance, the number is converted into an arithmetic number and written in 3 digits before " For substances in Appendix 2 of the same order (class 2 designated chemical substances), "1-" is indicated by adding "2-" in front of the three-digit notation with the number as an arithmetic number.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 31 August 2021, the Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced the cut-off exemption of one substance in the deleterious drugs group, pursuant to the Enforcement Rule of the Act on Securing Quality, Efficacy, and Safety of Products Including Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices (医薬品、医療機器等の品質、有効性及び安全性の確保等に関する法律施行規則) (Enforcement Rule of the Pharmaceuticals Act).

The change was effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

Article 44, Clauses 1 and 2 of the Enforcement Rule of the Pharmaceuticals Act require certain drugs that are designated by the Minister as poisonous or deleterious based on advice from the Pharmaceutical Affairs and Food Sanitation Council to be labeled as such on their containers or wrappings.

Labels should be designed with white boxed letters with a black background for the poisonous drugs, and with red boxed letters with a white background for deleterious drugs.

Annex Table 3 of the Enforcement Rule of the Pharmaceuticals Act is the list of poisonous and deleterious drugs. An example of one of these deleterious drugs is (S)-6-methoxy-alpha-methyl-2-naphthaleneacetic acid and its formula. 

On 31 August 2021, the MHLW announced that 100 mg or less of (S)-6-methoxy-alpha-methyl-2-naphthaleneacetic acid per tablet would be exempted from the list.

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers of the listed substances should abide by the labeling rule.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

Japan has designated five substances as narcotics and three others as stimulants under the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act and Stimulant Drugs Control Law. Published on 8 September 2021, the new designations will take effect on 8 October 2021.

3E Analysis :

Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that five substances and their salts are now classified as narcotics. Some examples are below:

  • 1-[1-(3-methoxyphenyl) cyclohexyl] piperidine
  • 1-(1,2-diphenylethyl) piperidine

According to the MHLW, all of the five substances were formerly classified as designated drugs under the Japanese Pharmaceutical Act. Their classification was revoked due to the new designation for tighter controls.

In parallel, the MHLW announced that three substances and their salts are now classified as stimulants. Some examples are below:

  • 8-bromo-6-(2-fluorophenyl)-1-metyl-4H-s- triazole [4,3-a][1,4] benzodiazepine
  • 6-(2-chlorophenyl)-1-metyl-8-nitro-4H-s-triazole [4,3-a][1,4] benzodiazepine

Because five substances are now designated as narcotics, those substances are deleted from the list of designated pharmatheticals for medical care.

Business Impact :

Companies dealing with any of the newly designated substances will be subject to requirements under the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act or Stimulant Drugs Control Law, such as obtaining licenses or designations as manufacturers, suppliers, importers, exporters, etc., after 8 October 2021.

If the URL of the source documents is no longer valid, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com for a copy (PDF, in Japanese).

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 25 August 2021, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that three substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of these substances other than for the purpose of medical care. The amendment went into effect 10 days after the announcement.

3E Analysis :

Under Japan's Pharmaceutical Law, designated pharmaceuticals are chemical substances that are allowed to be used for preventive medical care, medical diagnosis, and medical practice when the purpose has been proven to cause a low risk of harm and danger to the human body.

The following three substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care:

  • Ethyl 2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-indole-3-carboxamide]-3-methylbutanoate and its salts
  • 2-cyclohexyl-1-phenyl-2-(pyrrolidin-1-yl)ethan-1-one and its salts
  • 2-(methylamino)-1-(thiophen-2-yl)propan-1-one and its salts

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Since the substances are now listed as designated drugs, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of the substances, other than for the purpose of medical care, are banned.

Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including penalty fees and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropic Control Law.

Please note that the source link may not work. For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
This WO is not to reflect the regulation change but the technical change in NITE database. NITE is updating its database to include CAS RN correction, translation name correction, or government appointed number provision or etc.

 

Appendix 9 of the ISHL Enforcement Cabinet Order lists dangerous substances and may cause health issues for workers. Companies providing these substances, therefore, must label the name of the substance and must notify the recipient with information regarding these substances, including the composition and impact on the human body. Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) and risk assessments are also required for substances on this list.

Appendix 2 of the ISHL Enforcement Ministerial Ordinance sets the threshold of those substances in the formula.

Labelling is stipurated in Article 18 of the Order and Article 30 of the Rule. 

SDS and risk assessments are stipurated in Article 18-2 of the Order and Article 34-2 of the Rule.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
On 30 July 2021, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) jointly published Notice No. 4, adding 206 chemical substances to the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL) inventory. These newly added substances have been designated as General Chemical Substances (一般化学物質), effective 30 July 2021. 

Pursuant to the Act on the Evaluation of Chemical Substances and Regulation of Their Manufacture, etc., commonly known as the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL), the Ministries were notified that these substances are slated for new manufacture or import in/to Japan (i.e., New Chemical Substances). After evaluation, they are now designated as General Chemical Substances and added to the CSCL inventory. 

Manufacturers and importers of these General Chemical Substances in a quantity of one ton or more per year are subject to an annual reporting requirement under the CSCL.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese) if the link has expired, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.
