The additions are effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

Article 44, Clause 1 and 2 of the Enforcement Rule of the Act on Securing Quality, Efficacy, and Safety of Products Including Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices (Enforcement Rule of the Pharmaceuticals Act) requires certain drugs that are designated by the Minister as poisonous or deleterious based on advice from the Pharmaceutical Affairs and Food Sanitation Council to be labeled as such on their containers or wrappings.

Labels should be designed with white boxed letters with a black background for the poisonous drugs, and with red boxed letters with a white background for deleterious drugs.

Annex Table 3 of the Enforcement Rule of the Pharmaceuticals Act is the list of poisonous and deleterious drugs. The MHLW added the following drugs for regulation under the law:

  • Poisonous: Risdiplam and its formula
  • Deleterious: Zinutuximab and its formula

The MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers of the listed substances should abide by the labeling rule.

Alert Summary :

On 17 June 2021, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that two substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of these substances other than for the purpose of medical care. The amendment is effective 10 days from the announcement.

3E Analysis :

Designated pharmaceuticals under Japan's Pharmaceutical Law are chemical substances that are allowed to be used for preventive medical care, medical diagnosis, and medical practice when the purpose has been proven to cause low risk of harm and danger to the human body.

On 17 June 2021, MHLW announced that two substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care.

  • β-Hydroxythiofentanyl and its salts
  • 4F-MDMB-BICA or 4F-MDMB-BUTICA and its salts

MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

As the substances are now listed as designated drugs, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of the substances, other than for the purpose of medical care, are banned.

Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including penalty fees and imprisonment.

In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropic Control Law.

The Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 192 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) inventory on 25 June 2021. The additions are effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

For worker safety, ISHL's Clause 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and to report their test results if such substances—intended for manufacture or import—are not listed as existing.

Clause 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 25 June 2021, MHLW announced 192 new chemical substances, including adamantane-1-yl-ethyl-oxalate.

The MHLW provided no CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should consult with the updated chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain the necessity for harmfulness testing and reporting.

On 21 April 2021, Japan’s Prime Minister and competent ministries (Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), Ministry of the Environment (MOE), and Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW)) jointly published the amended Cabinet Order of the Enforcement of the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL).

Among others, the central point of the amendment was the addition of perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) to the list of Class I Specified Chemical Substances.

The amendment will go into effect on 22 October 2021.

3E Analysis :

Article 28 of the CSCL mandates that handlers of Class I Specified Chemical Substances follow the technical standards for handling certain products that use Class I Specified Chemical Substances.

The Cabinet Order lists the product item for each Class I Specified Chemical Substance.

The following products have been added to the Cabinet Order by this amendment:

  • Perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) as a Class I Specified Chemical Substance
  • Products such as fire extinguishers, floor wax, anti-reflection agents used in semiconductor manufacturing, etc.

Business Impact :

Importers, manufacturers, and handlers of PFOAs should consult with the Cabinet Order to comply with the regulation. The importation of products that use Class I Specified Chemical Substances is prohibited.

Alert Summary :

On 19 April 2021, Japan’s Ministry of the Environment (MOE) released a revision to the list of categories Y and Z noxious liquid substances under the Act on Prevention of Marine Pollution and Maritime Disaster (海洋汚染等及び海上災害の防止に関する法律). This revision added six substances and their coefficients to the list. The revision took effect on the same date.

3E Analysis :

The Act on Prevention of Marine Pollution and Maritime Disaster is the law implementing the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL) in Japan.

Annex II of MARPOL stipulates provisions to prevent marine pollution by noxious liquid substances in bulk. The noxious liquid substances are categorized into four categories, namely Categories X, Y, Z, and OS (other substances). Category X is the highest hazard level and the hazard levels degrade in alphabetical order (i.e., hazard level: X>Y>Z). Category OS is comprised of substances considered to pose no hazard to the marine environment.

On 19 April 2021, in accordance with the Maritime Environment Protection Committee (MEPC) decision, the MOE added three substances to category Y and three substances and their coefficients to category Z:

  • Y: 2-Mercaptoethanol, 25
  • Z: Hexanetricarbonitrile, 0

Business Impact :

Companies can now transport newly added liquid substances in bulk by complying with the requirements imposed on the category under the act.

If the URL for the source document is no longer valid, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com for a copy (PDF, in Japanese).

On 31 March 2021, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) published a list of five chemical substances that have been deleted as priority assessment chemical substances (PACS) under the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL). M-chloroaniline and others are deleted.

Business Impact :

As to the manufacture/import of the five PACS that have been deleted from under the CSCL in the Japanese fiscal year 2020 (i.e., April 2020 to March 2021), companies shall still submit a report about them as general chemical substances by the end of June 2021.

Alert Summary :

On 15 January 2021, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced an amendment to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. The update adds four food additives to the list of food additives that are authorized for use in food products. This update is effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

The Food Sanitation Law prohibits the manufacture, sale, or import of any food product not in keeping with the list of authorized food additives and food contact materials.

Article 12 of Japan's Food Sanitation Law provides that additives may be added to the list of designated food additives as shown in Appendix 1 to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule.

Ammonium hydrogen sulfite water, chitin glucan, DL-potassium tartrate, and vinylimidazole/vinylpyrrolidone copolymer are added with this update.

Chapter 2, Section C (test reagents) and Section D (component and preservation standard) of Food, additives or etc. Standards (MHLW Notice No. 370) are also amended concerning the addition of these additives. Moreover, Section F (usage standard) has newly added standard portion, including "chitin glucan shall be only used in grape juice and wine," or "usage limit is five gram per liter." 

No CAS RNs are provided by MHLW.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers, importers, distributors, and interested stakeholders should take note that the new additives are authorized for use immediately.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese) if the link is not of use, please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 25 December 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan added 183 chemical substances to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) Inventory. The additions are effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

For worker safety, ISHL's Clause 1 of Article 57-4 requires manufacturers and importers of chemical substances to conduct toxicity tests to determine their potential harm and to report their test results, if such substances - intended for manufacture or import - are not listed as existing. 

Clause 3 of Article 57-4 of the ISHL requires MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the ministry.

On 25 December 2020, MHLW announced 183 new chemical substances, including [(1S)-1- isocyanatoethyl]benzene.

The MHLW provided no CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

Manufacturers and importers should consult with the updated chemical substance inventory when they intend to manufacture or import chemical substances to ascertain the necessity of harmfulness testing and reporting. 

If the link to the source document has expired, for a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at 3EMonitorSupport@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 29 May 2020, the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications of Japan (MIAC) amended the list of hazardous materials that are subject to reporting obligations for storage and handling required by the Fire Service Law (FSL). Aluminum trichloride has been added to the list. The updated list will come into effect on 1 December 2020.

3E Analysis :

The Fire Service Law (FSL) Art.9-3 requires persons to register the storage or handling of hazardous materials that are prone to chemical accidents with the Fire Station. 

The FSL delegates the Hazardous Material Regulation Cabinet Order to define hazardous materials. Cabinet Order Art.1-10 and Appendix Tables 1 and 2 partly itemize such hazardous materials and partly delegate the Ministerial Order to define such hazardous materials. The Ministerial Order Articles 1 and 2 itemize such materials.

The MIAC added aluminum trichloride and the formulation which includes aluminum trichloride to Article 2 of the Ministerial Order as Item Number 31. 

Business Impact :

Companies that store or handle aluminum trichloride and the formulation which includes aluminum trichloride shall register their storage or handling with the fire station.  

Overall, this right-to-know list of hazardous substances must be reported to the Fire Department or Station Chief if a company stores any of these substances above the designated thresholds.

If the URL of the source document is no longer valid, please contact us at 3EMonitorSupport@Verisk3E.com for a copy (PDF, in Japanese).
SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Short Name: Japan. Fire Service Law, Storage/Handling Reporting Substances

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) are working actively to classify chemical substances in accordance with GHS. Japan's National Institute of Technology and Evaluation (NITE) publishes updates on their progress periodically.  Companies are not required to adopt the classification results for GHS labeling and safety data sheets (SDS).  These classifications are references to assist businesses and other relevant parties in preparing GHS-based labeling and SDS. Businesses are not obliged to use these results but can use them at their own discretion. Businesses may also classify chemicals they deal with on their own.

NITE published errata;

on 6 October 2020 for the substances listed in 2019, and

on 4 December 2020 for the substances listed in 2008, 2009 and 2019.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 22 January 2021, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that four substances were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care, which bans the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of these substances other than for the purpose of medical care. The amendment is effective 10 days from the announcement.

3E Analysis :

"Designated pharmaceuticals" under Japan's Pharmaceutical Law are chemical substances that are allowed to be used for preventive medical care, medical diagnosis, and medical practice when the purpose has been proven to cause low risk of harm and danger to the human body.

On 22 January 2021, MHLW announced that four substances, including ethyl=2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide]-3,3-dimethylbutanoate and its salts, were added to the list of designated pharmaceuticals for medical care.

MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

As the substances are now listed as designated drugs, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of the substances, other than for the purpose of medical care, is banned. Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including penalty fees and imprisonment. In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropic Control Law.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at Support@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
On 15 January 2021, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced an amendment to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. The update adds four food additives to the list of food additives that are authorized for use in food products. This update is effective immediately.

The Food Sanitation Law prohibits the manufacture, sale, or import of any food product not in keeping with the list of authorized food additives and food contact materials.

Article 12 of Japan's Food Sanitation Law provides that additives may be added to the list of designated food additives as shown in Appendix 1 to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. 

Ammonium hydrogen sulfite water, Chitin glucan, DL-Potassium tartrate and Copolymer of Vinylimidazole/ Vinylpyrrolidone PVI/PVP are added with this update. 

Chapter 2, Section C (test reagents) and Section D (component and preservation standard) of Food, additives or etc. Standards (MHLW Notice No. 370) are also amended concerning the addition of these additives. Moreover, Section F (usage standard) has newly added standard portion such as "chitin glucan shall be only used in grape juice and wine," or "usage limit is five gram per liter." 

No CAS RNs are provided by MHLW.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 13 August 2020, the Ministry of Environment of Japan (MOE) announced that it updated Appendices 1 and 1-2 of the Enforcement Order of the Marine Pollution Prevention Law.

The updates will be effective on 1 January 2021.

3E Analysis :

The Marine Pollution Prevention Law is the law that regulates the discharge from ships, etc. of oil, noxious liquid, disposal, etc.

Appendix 1 (Noxious Substances List) of the Enforcement Order of the Marine Pollution Prevention Law is composed of X, Y, and Z substances. Category X is the highest hazard level. The hazard level degrades in alphabetical order (i.e., hazard level: X>Y>Z).

Appendix 1-2 of the Enforcement Order of the Marine Pollution Prevention Law is the Innoxious Substance List.

The 13 August 2020 updates from the MOE include the following:

  • Addition to the X substances of Appendix 1: alkylbenzene mixture (Naphthalene included only);
  • Deletion from the X substances of Appendix1: dimethyl adipate;
  • Addition to the Y substances of Appendix 1: dimethyl adipate;
  • Deletion from the Y substances of Appendix 1: ethylene glycol;
  • Addition to the Z substance of Appendix 1: ethylene glycol; 
  • Deletion from the Z substances of Appendix 1: benzenesulfonyl chloride; and
  • Additions to Appendix 1-2: triethylene glycol and propylene glycol.

CAS RNs were not provided by the source. 

Business Impact :

Any companies that transport the designated oil mixtures in bulk by ship shall comply with the requirements under the Act and Enforcement Order, including the discharge restriction.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at 3EMonitorSupport@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Appendix 9 of the ISHL Enforcement Cabinet Order lists dangerous substances and may cause health issues for workers. Companies providing these substances, therefore, must label the name of the substance and must notify the recipient with information regarding these substances, including the composition and impact on the human body. Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) and risk assessments are also required for substances on this list.

Appendix 2 of the ISHL Enforcement Ministerial Ordinance sets the threshold of those substances in the formula.

Labelling is stipurated in Article 18 of the Order and Article 30 of the Rule.  SDS and risk assessments are stipurated in Article 18-2 of the Order and Article 34-2 of the Rule.

Benzyl alcohol with a cut-off value of 1% is added to the list due to increased workplace injuries on 2 December 2020.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 26 August 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that six substances were added to the list of Designated Pharmaceuticals for Medical Care, banning the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of these substances other than for the purpose of medical care. The amendment is effective 10 days from the announcement.

3E Analysis :

"Designated pharmaceuticals" under Japan's Pharmaceutical Law are chemical substances that are allowed to be used for preventive medical care, medical diagnosis, and medical practice when the purpose has been proven to cause low risk of harm and danger to the human body.

On 26 August 2020, MHLW announced that six substances, including 4-methyl-1-phenyl-2-(pyrrolidine-1-il) pentane-1-one and its salts, were added to the list of Designated Pharmaceuticals for Medical Care.

MHLW did not provide CAS RNs.

Business Impact :

As the substances are now listed as designated drugs, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of the substances, other than for the purpose of medical care, is banned. Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions, including penalty fees and imprisonment. In addition, the listed pharmaceuticals may be subject to regulations under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substance Control Law and the Narcotics and Psychotropic Control Law.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at 3EMonitorSupport@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 29 May 2020, the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications of Japan (MIAC) amended the list of hazardous materials that are subject to reporting obligations for storage and handling required by the Fire Service Law (FSL). Aluminum trichloride has been added to the list. The updated list will come into effect on 1 December 2020.

3E Analysis :

The Fire Service Law (FSL) Art.9-3 requires persons to register the storage or handling of hazardous materials that are prone to chemical accidents with the Fire Station. 

The FSL delegates the Hazardous Material Regulation Cabinet Order to define hazardous materials. Cabinet Order Art.1-10 and Appendix Tables 1 and 2 partly itemize such hazardous materials and partly delegate the Ministerial Order to define such hazardous materials. The Ministerial Order Articles 1 and 2 itemize such materials.

The MIAC added aluminum trichloride and the formulation which includes aluminum trichloride to Article 2 of the Ministerial Order as Item Number 31. 

Business Impact :

Companies that store or handle aluminum trichloride and the formulation which includes aluminum trichloride shall register their storage or handling with the fire station.  

Overall, this right-to-know list of hazardous substances must be reported to the Fire Department or Station Chief if a company stores any of these substances above the designated thresholds.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 18 June 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced an amendment to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. The update adds one food additive, difenoconazole, to the list of food additives that are authorized for use in food products. This update is effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

The Food Sanitation Law prohibits the manufacture, sale, or import of any food product not in keeping with the list of authorized food additives and food contact materials.

Article 12 of Japan's Food Sanitation Law provides that additives may be added to the list of designated food additives as shown in Appendix 1 to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. Difenoconazole is added with this update. 

Business Impact :

Manufacturers, importers, distributors, and interested stakeholders should take note that the new additive is authorized for use immediately.

-------

The above amendment to the Law Enforcement Rule requires Standards to make changes accordingly. On the same day, No. 370 Chapter 2 (additives) Section F (usage standards) newly inserts two sentences as follows:

Difenoconazole must not be used in the food except for potatos. Difenoconazole must be used in the way so that the residue of the Difenoconazole does not exceed 0.004 gram per one kilogram of potatos.

Alert Summary :

On 27 May 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry of Japan (METI) announced the renewal of the Chemical Weapons List by adding eight Specific Substances.

The renewal came into effect on 7 June 2020.  

3E Analysis :

The Act on the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and the Regulation of Specific Chemicals of Japan (Act) implements the Chemical Weapons Convention. The Act prohibits the production, possession, or transfer of chemical weapons or their precursors. 

Permits are required for Cabinet Order Table 1 substances. Reporting is required for Tables 1, 2, and 3 substances.

The METI announced the addition of eight chemical substances as Specific Substances into Table 1, including:

  • N-[bis(diethylamino)methylidene]-P-methylphosphonamidic acid fluoride; and
  • N,N,N',N'-tetraalkyl-N,N'-bis{[3-(dimethylcarbamoyloxy)pyridin-2-yl]methyl}ethanebis(amidium) dibromide (tetraalkyl's alkyl C<10).

Business Impact :

Companies that engage in the production, possession, or transfer of newly added Specific Substances are now subject to permit and reporting requirements.

On 8 July 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced the addition of 10 substances to the list of narcotics and one substance to the list of psychotropics regulated under the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act (麻薬、麻薬原料植物、向精神薬及び麻薬向精神薬原料を指定する政令) .

The additions will be effective from 7 August 2020.

3E Analysis :

Ten substances, including their salts, are now classified as narcotics. Included are:

  • methyl 2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide]-3-methylbutanoate; and
  • methyl 2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-indole-3-carboxamide]-3・3-dimethylbutanoate.

One substance, including its salts, is now classified as psychotropic:

  • 8-chloro-6-(2-fluorophenyl)-1-methyl-4H-[1・2・4] triazolo[4・3-a][1・4] benzodiazepine.

Business Impact :

Companies dealing with any of the newly designated narcotics and psychotropics will be subject to the requirements of the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Act, such as obtaining licenses as manufacturers, suppliers, importers, exporters, etc. beginning 7 August 2020.
SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Short Name: Japan. Narcotic and Psychotropic Control Law Designation Order

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 8 July 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that seven substances were deleted from the list of Designated Pharmaceuticals for Medical Care, banning the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of these substances other than for the purpose of medical care.

The amendment will be effective from 7 August 2020. Acts taken before the effective date will not be subject to penalty.

3E Analysis :

"Designated pharmaceuticals" under Japan's Pharmaceutical Law are chemical substances that are allowed to be used for preventive medical care, medical diagnosis, and medical practice when the purpose has been proven to cause low risk of harm and danger to the human body.

On 8 July 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced that the seven substances that were deleted from the list of Designated Pharmaceuticals for Medical Care included:

  • methyl=2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide]-3-methylbutanoate
  • methyl=2-[1-(5-fluoropentyl)-1H-indole-3-carboxamide]-3・3-dimethylbutanoate

This change to the list is the mirror effect of the amendment of the Narcotics and Psychotropics Control Law Designation Order. The Order newly adds substances as Narcotics. Thus, such substances are no longer allowed for use for medical care and are deleted from this list. 

Business Impact :

As the substances are no longer listed as designated drugs, the manufacture, import, sale, possession, and use of the substances are banned. Companies that violate this amendment may be subject to enforcement actions that include penalty fees and imprisonment. Acts taken before the effective date of 7 August 2020 will not be subject to penalty.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 18 June 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) announced an amendment to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. The update adds one food additive, difenoconazole, to the list of food additives that are authorized for use in food products. This update is effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

The Food Sanitation Law prohibits the manufacture, sale, or import of any food product not in keeping with the list of authorized food additives and food contact materials.

Article 12 of Japan's Food Sanitation Law provides that additives may be added to the list of designated food additives as shown in Appendix 1 to the Food Sanitation Law Enforcement Rule. Difenoconazole is added with this update. 

Business Impact :

Manufacturers, importers, distributors, and interested stakeholders should take note that the new additive is authorized for use immediately.

Alert Summary :

On 26 June 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) of Japan announced 257 chemical substances newly added to the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) Inventory. The additions are effective immediately.

3E Analysis :

For worker safety, Article 57-4 Clause 1 of the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) requires manufacturers or importers to conduct harmfulness tests and report the test results from the chemical substances that the manufacturers or importers intend to manufacture or import if such chemical substances are not listed as existing chemical substances. 

Article 57-4 Clause 3 of the ISHL requires the MHLW to announce new chemical substances as manufacturers and importers report them to the MHLW.

On 26 June 2020, the MHLW announced 257 new chemical substances, including 2-amino-3,4-difluorobenzaldehyde, 2-(2-azido-3,4-difluorophenyl)-1,3-dioxolane, or etc.

Small circle in the Food Categories means "you can use it for this food." Hyphen means "you cannot use it for this food."

I means the temperature can reach at 70 degree Celsius. II means the temperature can reach at 100 Celsius. III means the temperature can be over 100 Celsius.

1 means that it has a polymer or a crosslinked structure with glass transition temperature or ball pressure temperature of 150 ° C or higher, and is categorized as the polymer with melting point of 150 ° C or higher (excluding those corresponding to 4 to 7).

2 means that it is categorized as the polymer with water absorption rate of 0.1% or less (excluding those corresponding to 1 and 4 to 7).

3 means that it is categorized as the polymer with water absorption rate of more than 0.1% (excluding polymers corresponding to 1 and 4 to 7).

4 means that it is the polymer the ratio of the portion derived from vinyl chloride or vinylidene chloride of which is 50% or more.

5 means that it is the polymer of the ratio of the part derived from ethylene of which is 50% or more.

6 means that it is the polymer of the ratio of the portion derived from propylene of which is 50% or more.

7 means that it is the polymer of the ratio of the part derived from terephthalic acid and ethylene glycol of which is 50 mol% or more.

Re 3. above, please capture substance name (英名) and CAS#.

Excel file CAS (2) is Table 2.

Please capture MHLW number (整理番号), Sequence number (通し番号), substance name (英名), CAS# and Use limitation in % of each Synthetic Resin type (合成樹脂区分別使用制限). Types are 1-7 described above.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
The Specifications and Standards for Foods, Food Additives, etc. is one of the main standards regulating food contact materials in Japan. It introduces the positive list system for raw materials used for synthetic resins. Specifically, only raw materials identified on the positive list are permitted for use in synthetic resins. Similarly, a positive list system is also applied for the additives and coating agents used in resins.

The positive lists are comprised of two tables.

Table No. 1

Table No. 1 is further divided into three sub-sections, including the:

  • Positive list of base polymers in plastics;
  • Positive list of base polymers in coating resins; and
  • Positive list of minor monomers that can be used for polymerization of base polymers.

The first two sub-sections are organized by the plastic or resin type, such as polyethylene (PE) and ethylene-vinyl acetate-vinyl alcohol copolymer (EVOH), and specify the base polymers that are permitted in each one of these. They contain the Japanese name, permitted food type, permitted use temperature, and resin group number, as well as additional notes and restrictions.

The list of minor monomers that are permitted for use in the polymerization process of base polymers provides the Japanese name of the identified monomers. More than 98 wt% of the components of a base polymer must be identified in the positive list of base polymers. The remaining components must be the copolymers of the monomers identified on the list of minor monomers. These base polymers and minor monomers are specified under Table No. 1.

Table No. 2

The positive list of additives contains information on the Japanese names of permitted additives in food contact resins and the usage restriction percentage for each category of resin. 

Along with the positive lists above, the following lists are also of importance:

  • The list of substances, which are continuously under scrutiny for inclusion on the positive lists.
  • The English name and CAS RN of each material above, provided in the separate tables by the MHLW as references.
SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Short Name: Japan. MHLW Food Contact Materials Positive List

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Alert Summary :

On 31 March 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) approved psicose epimerase for use as a food additive. The approval went into effect immediately.

3E Analysis :

Pursuant to Article 10 of the Food Sanitation Law, food additives designated by the Minister of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) as posing no risks to human health are authorized to be sold, manufactured, imported, processed, used, stored, or displayed for sale. The Ministry Order of the law Table No.1 provides the list of those additives.  

The designated food additives must comply with the Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc.

ISHL Art. 57 and Art.57-2  require companies to put label and conduct SDS for certain materials. These materials  are listed in the Art.18, Art.18-2, and Table 9 of Cabinet Order of ISHL. 

In 2017, the MHLW was considering the additional revision to the list for several materials, and some of them were dropped from the addition, factoring in the shortness of material risk to the health issue. But there was certain amount of risk from the long time exposure of them. Thus it was deemed appropriate to ask the industry for their best effort to conduct label and SDS.  And it was also deemed appropriate that calling for industry's attention on the fact that the power form of them were regulated by the existing Dust Prevention Ministerial Order and its compliance was important.  

Source Link to the Ministerial Order:

https://elaws.e-gov.go.jp/search/elawsSearch/elaws_search/lsg0500/detail?lawId=354M50002000018

In terms of power form of three materials (talc, magnesium oxide, and amorphous silica), MHLW issued the circular (Tsutatsu in Japanese) on 24 October 2017 to the local authorities and companies to notify two points above; best effort for label and SDS, and compliance to Dust Prevention Ministerial Order.

Source Link to the Circular:

https://www.mhlw.go.jp/web/t_doc?dataId=00tc2991&dataType=1&pageNo=1

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Food Sanitization Law was amended in 1995 in large scale. Article 2 of the additional clauses on Food Sanitization Law, ordered the MHLW to compose the list of Existing Additives List in order to make it possible to keep using (natural) additives, which have been used for a long time without causing associated health issues, such as persimon tannin, etc.

Article 2-3, Clause 1 of the additional clauses on Food Sanitization Law, authorizes the MHLW to compose the list of Planned Deletion Additives and to announce the plan. Clause 5 of the same Article requires the MHLW to delete the announced additives from the Existing Food Additives List within one year from the announcement and to announce the deletion.

On 26 February 2020, the Japanese Ministry of Health Labor and Welfare (MHLW) announced the deletion of nine food additives from the Existing Food Additives List. The deletions became effective immediately.

For the avoidance of confusion in future, Existing Additives list was originally created in 1996 as MHLW Announcement (KOKUJI) No. 120. The changes to the list have been provided by new MHLW Announcements, but the orininal list and its Announcement number 120 keeps its identity.

The Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) Designated Carcinogens list contains substances that are considered to cause potential harm to the human body, including the risk of causing cancer.  The list is disclosed as the part of the Guideline and the original Guideline No. 23 was disclosed on 10 October 2012.

The Guideline has been updated proximately once a year since 2012 and the Guideline No. has been growing 24, 25, 26, and so on. On 7 February 2020, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare (MHLW) issued the Guideline No. 27 and added two substances to the Designated Carcinogens list under the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL). 

The two substances which were added to this list on 7 February 2020 are: Methyl acrylate (CAS#96-33-3) and Acrolein (CAS#107-02-8).

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
On 5 December 2019, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) announced its renewed list of Hazardous Chemical Substances, which shall be included in the Annual Report of the Work Exposed to Hazardous Chemical Substances submitted by employers to MHLW.  The effective date is 1 January 2020.

Every year, the advisory committee to MHLW carries out initial risk assessments and evaluations of selected hazardous chemical substances to evaluate possible threats to worker safety. To collect information on such substances, Article 95-6 of the Ordinance on Industrial Safety and Health requires employers, who have manufactured and handled such substances in a volume of 500 kilogram and more within a year, to submit the standardized annual report.

Such selected hazardous chemical substances are annually reviewed and announced by MHLW. Three substances are deleted from the list and one substance is added to the list. 

Deleted

1) Tetrahydrofuran, <0.1%;

2) 2,4,6-Trichlorophenol, <0.1%; and

3) Furfuryl alcohol, <1%.

Added

Molybdenum Compound (only Molybdenum trioxide), <0.1%.

The companies manufacturing, importing, or handling these chemical substances should be aware of the renewed list, monitor their handling volume of substances listed on the list, and submit the standardized annual report to MHLW.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Based on Enforcement Order of Marine Pollution Prevention Law, Article 1(2), the oil mixtures listed in Appendix 1 that are hazardous from the standpoint of conservation of the marine environment is amended.Two substances are deleted from the list:1. Alkanes (having 10 to 17 carbons or mixtures thereof) and jet fuel oils (having a concentration of jet fuel oil of less than 75% by volume); and2. Alkanes (having 10 to 26 carbons or mixtures thereof) and mixtures of heavy or light oil(having a concentration of heavy oil or light oil of less than 75% by volume)
Alert Summary :

On 3 October 2019, Japan’s Ministry of the Environment (MOE) published Notice No. 17 and 18, through which the Enforcement Order of Marine Pollution Prevention Law, Appendix 1 is revised. The amendment enters into force immediately.

3E Analysis :

Based on the Enforcement Order of Marine Pollution Prevention Law, Article 1(2), the oil mixtures listed in Appendix 1 that are hazardous from the standpoint of conservation of the marine environment are amended.

Two substances are deleted from the list:

1. Alkanes (having 10 to 17 carbons or mixtures thereof) and jet fuel oils (having a concentration of jet fuel oil of less than 75% by volume); and

2. Alkanes (having 10 to 26 carbons or mixtures thereof) and mixtures of heavy or light oil (having a concentration of heavy oil or light oil of less than 75% by volume).

Three substances are added to a category x:

1. Reaction product of N- (2-aminoethyl) -2-aminoethanol, toluoyl oleate and diethyl sulfate (Transported in a mixed state with hazardous or non-hazardous substances in terms of conservation of marine environments)

  • Modulus: 10,000

2. 2-alkyl-1-benzyl-4·5-dihydro-1-hydroxyethyl-imidazolium chloride (Limited to those transported in a mixed state with hazardous or non-hazardous substances in terms of conservation of marine environments)

  • Modulus: 1,000

3. Alkyl-1-benzyl-pyridinium chloride (limited to alkyl groups having 1 or 2 carbon atoms and mixtures thereof)

  • Modulus: 1,000

Five substances are added to a category y:

1. Diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid pentapotassium salt solution (concentration limited to 40 wt%) (Limited to those transported in a mixed state with hazardous or non-hazardous substances in terms of conservation of marine environments)

  • Modulus: 1

2. Diethylenetriamine pentamethylenephosphonic acid ammonium salt solution (concentration limited to 60 wt% or less)

  • Modulus: 1

3. Diethylenetriamine pentamethylene phosphonic acid pentasodium salt solution (Limited to those transported in a mixed state with hazardous or non-hazardous substances in terms of conservation of marine environments)

  • Modulus: 1

4. Hexahydro-1·3·5-trimethyl-1·3·5-triazine solution (concentration limited to 45wt% or less)

  • Modulus: 10

5. Polyoxyethylene nonyl phenyl ether phosphate (Limited to those transported in a mixed state with hazardous or non-hazardous substances in terms of conservation of marine environments)

  • Modulus: 10

Two substances are deleted from a category y:

1. Alkanes (limited to mixtures of isoalkanes and noralkanes with 10 to 17 carbon atoms); and

2. Alkanes (limited to mixtures of 5 to 7 carbon atoms, excluding mixtures of 6 and 7 carbon atoms)

One substance is revised from a category y:

1. Hexahydro-1·3·5-triethano-1·3·5-triazine (Limited to those transported in a mixed state with hazardous or non-hazardous substances in terms of conservation of marine environments) --> Hexahydro-1·3·5-triethano-1·3·5-triazine solution.

Business Impact :

Any companies that transport the designated oil mixtures in bulk by ship shall comply with the requirements under the Act and Enforcement Order including the discharge restriction.

For a copy of the source document (PDF, in Japanese), please contact us at 3EMonitorSupport@Verisk3E.com.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) announced that the following nine substances, including their salts, are now classified as narcotics:

  • N-(1-Amino-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)-1-(cyclohexylmethyl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide;
  • N-(1-Amino-3,3-dimethyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)-1-(4-fluorobenzyl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide;
  • 2-Ethylamino-1-(3,4-methylenedioxyphenyl)pentan-1-one;
  • 1-(4-Cyanobutyl)-N-(2-phenylpropan-2-yl)-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide;
  • N-(1-Phenethylpiperidin-4-yl)-N-phenylcyclopropanecarboxamide;
  • N-(4-Fluorophenyl)-N-(1-phenethylpiperidin-4-yl)butanamide;
  • N-(2-Fluorophenyl)-N-(1-phenethylpiperidin-4-yl)propenamide;
  • Methyl 2-[1-(4-fluorobenzyl)-1H-indazole-3- carboxamido]-3-methylbutanoate; and
  • 2-Methoxy-N-(1-phenethylpiperidin-4-yl)-N-phenylacetamide.

In parallel, the following two substances, including their salts, have been designated as Specified Narcotic or Psychotropic Raw Materials:

  • Methyl 2-methyl-3-(3,4-methylenedioxyphenyl)- oxirane-2-carboxylate (excluding its mixtures in concentrations of 50% or less); and
  • 2-Methyl-3-(3,4-methylenedioxyphenyl)- oxirane-2-carboxylic acid (excluding its mixtures in concentrations of 50% or less).

3-Oxo-2-phenylbutanamide, its salts and mixtures containing either the substance or its salts are also designated as stimulant raw materials under the Stimulant Drugs Control Law.

According to MHLW, all of these substances were formerly classified as Designated Drugs under the Japanese Pharmaceutical Act. Their classification was revoked due to the new designation for tighter controls.

Japan. Narcotic Psychotropic Precursors Exclusion List (Narcotic and Psychotropic Control Law Enforcement Rule MHLW No. 14, Appendix 3, 18 April 1953, as amended through 28 June 2019)

2. Add the following two substances (including cut-off values for exemption) to the database, referring to the tab "別表第三（第四十五条の八関係）" in the attached source document "20190628麻薬取締法." These two substances are highlighted in yellow:

  • Methyl 2-methyl-3-(3,4-methylenedioxyphenyl)-oxirane-2-carboxylate and its salts, equal or below 50%
  • 2-Methyl-3-(3,4-methylenedioxyphenyl)-oxirane-2-carboxylic acid and its salts, equal or below 50%

NOTE: The attached cut-off value shown in the excel file is >50% for these two substances. In our database, however, this value should be equal or below 50%. The rationale behind this is that the source document 別表第三（第四十五条の八関係）designates precursors of narcotic or psychotropic drugs, if the concentration level is above the listed cut-off values. What we capture under this database, however, is the exclusions that are NOT designated as precursors of narcotic or psychotropic drugs. As a result, we'll need to capture information on substances that do not exceed the cut-off values.

Thank you.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
Please:

- Revise DB List Phrase to:

Japan. ISHL Hazardous Substances for Annual Worker Exposure Reporting (MHLW Public Notice No. 25 of 16 February 2006, as amended through 28 December 2018);

- Change the Short List Description to:

This is a list of hazardous chemical substances of which manufacture or handling in a quantity of 500kg or more is subject to an annual reporting on worker exposure. Companies manufacturing or handling the listed substances, including mixtures containing them in specific concentrations, are required to submit an annual report to the Head of Labor Standards Supervision Office under certain conditions.

- Refer to the attached Excel (Title: ISHL Hazardous Substances for Annual Reporting_2019) and add/remove substances per the instructions provided under Column M (i.e. add seven substances of manufacture/handling in 2019 while removing another seven substances of manufacture/handling in 2017). Please make sure to capture all the necessary information in the table.

Summary of Changes

On 28 December 2018, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) released a list of seven hazardous substances subject to an annual reporting obligation under the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL) for the manufacture/handling during 2019.

The following seven substances, including preparations containing them in concentrations of 0.1% or more by weight, are subject to the annual reporting obligation: 

  • Asphalt (CAS RN 8052-42-4);
  • Ethylene glycol mono-n-butyl ether, also known as butyl cellosolve (CAS RN 111-76-2);
  • o-Cresol (CAS RN 95-48-7);
  • Cyclohexanone (CAS RN 108-94-1);
  • 1,1-Dichloroethylene (CAS RN 75-35-4);
  • Furfural (CAS RN 98-01-1); and
  • Methyl tert-butyl ether, also known as MTBE (CAS RN 1634-04-4).

Companies manufacturing or handling these substances, including preparations containing them in the concentrations of 0.1% or more, will be required to submit an annual report to the Head of Labor Standards Supervision Office between 1 January 2020 to 31 December 2020. The requirement applies when all of the following conditions are met:

- Manufacture or handling takes place from 1 January 2019 to 31 December 2019;

- Manufactured or handled quantity is 500 kilograms or more; and

- There is a risk of worker exposure to gases, steams or dusts of the substances at workplaces.

On 4 July 2018, Japan’s Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) published the amendments to the Act on the Protection of the Ozone Layer Through the Control of Specified Substances and Other Measures (hereafter, Ozone Layer Protection Act) in the Official Gazette. The amended Act will come into force on 1 January 2019, except for certain requirements. 

The purpose of the amended Ozone Layer Protection Act of 4 July 2018 is to regulate the production and consumption of 18 hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) to align  it with the so-called Kigali Amendment, adopted at the 28th Meeting of the Parties to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer held on 15 October 2016 in Kigali, Rwanda.

As a result, businesses dealing with the targeted 18 HFCs will be subject to controls to reduce them, such as permits for manufacture and approvals for import as of 1 January 2019.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
Please:

- revise the DB List Phrase to:

Japan. Ministerial Order of Marine Pollution Prevention Law (Ministry of Environment Public Notices No. 148, 149 and others, as amended through No.81, 5 October 2018)

- revise Short List Description to:

This is a list of hazardous marine pollutants designated by Japan's Ministry of Environment through multiple Public Notices (e.g. Public Notice No. 148 of 15 December 2006 and Public Notices on evaluation results for non-evaluated liquid substances). Disposal of these substances from vessels or marine facilities is either prohibited or restricted, depending on the category. A few non-hazardous pollutants which are not restricted are also listed.

- carry out a full-proof of the current DB list against the uploaded Excel file ( Tabs "国際委判定 (20181005)" and "海防未査定（20150611)").

Note: It has been confirmed that substances under Tab "海防未査定 (20150611)" need to be CAPTURED by this DB. It is clearly mentioned in the legal source document (Order for Enforcment of the Marine Pollution Prevention Act, 1-C (ハ), 2-C (ハ) and 3-C (ハ) of the Annex Table 1). 

Summary of Changes

On 5 October 2018, Japan’s Ministry of the Environment (MOE) released revisions to the lists of Categories X, Y and Z noxious liquid substances under the Act on Prevention of Marine Pollution and Maritime Disaster (海洋汚染等及び海上災害の防止に関する法律), adding a few substances in each list. The revised lists took effect on the same date.

As a result of the revision of 5 October 2018, three substances for Category X, four substances for Category Y and two substances for Category Z were newly added. MOE provides a list of newly added substances online in English, together with corresponding categories and factors (No CAS RN is provided). “Ethylene glycol (>85%)/sodium alkyl carboxylates mixture” under Category Z on the list had been under Category Y prior to the revision of 5 October 2018.

In addition, as per further verification of the current DB, it turned out there is a gap between chemicals listed under the actual legal list and our DB list which requires a full-proof of the current DB list.

As per the amendments of 8 August 2018 to Ministerial Ordinance on Milk and Milk Products Concerning Compositional Standards, etc. (乳及び乳製品の成分規格等に関する省令), food containers/packages standards for formulated liquid milk are newly established.

Please:

1. Update DB List Phrase to:

Japan. Food Contact Materials for Milk and Milk Products (Ministerial Ordinance on Milk and Milk Products Concerning Compositional Standards, etc., MHLW No. 52, as amended through 8 August 2018)

Summary of Changes

Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) established on 8 August 2018, food standards under the Food Sanitation Law for formulated liquid milk to enable its manufacture and sales in Japan. While formulated liquid milk is marketed in many other countries, Japan did not allow manufacture or sales of it due to lack of applicable food safety standards previously. The standards took effect upon publication.

The newly established standards cover compositions, food additives, manufacture, storage and containers, etc. to assure safety of formulated liquid milk which is preservative at a normal temperature.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) published on 13 July 2018, the amended food standards for mineral water and newly established food standards for specific soybean curd (tofu) in the Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc. (食品、添加物等の規格基準) under the Food Sanitation Law (食品衛生法). These standards took effect upon publication except for more stringent standards on mineral water for which a six month grace period is granted.

For mineral water (defined as soft drinks of which raw material is only water), compositional and manufacturing standards were revised. With regard to the compositional standards, limits for the following substances were revised as below:

  • Zinc (CAS RN 7440-66-6): Removed (previously 5mg/L);
  • Antimony (CAS RN 7440-36-0): 0.005mg/L (newly established);
  • Arsenic (CAS RN 7440-38-2): 0.01mg/L (previously 0.05mg/L);
  • Manganese (CAS RN 7439-96-5): 0.4mg/L (previously 2mg/L);
  • Nitrite-nitrogen (CAS RN Not available): 0.04mg/L (newly established); and
  • Boron (CAS RN 7440-42-8): 5mg/L (previously 30mg/L as boric acid).

For tofu, since the previous standards required storage under refrigeration, food standards were newly established to allow storage and distribution of aseptic filling tofu at a room temperature. As a newly established compositional standard, any microorganisms which could be generated in tofu preserved at room temperature must not be detected in aseptic filling tofu preservative at room temperature. They must also conform to the newly established manufacturing standards.

Please revise "Short List Descriptin" as below:

Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL) inventory of existing and new chemical substances that may be manufactured in or imported into Japan. Many generic listings from the original source have been filled in with specific members of those generic groups by Ariel. CSCL exempts natural chemicals involving no chemical reactions (e.g. elements). Specific chemicals such as inorganic polymer compounds consisting only of existing chemicals are considered existing chemicals without listed in ENCS list.

Please revise "Short List Descriptin" as below:

An inventory of existing substances maintained by MHLW. Chemicals to be used in the workplace that are not on the ISHL Inventory are subject to testing and notification requirements. However, ISHL considers specific chemicals as existing substances without specifically listing them under ISHL Inventory. Examples are elements; naturally generated chemicals; radioactive substances; specific intermolecular compounds consisting of only existing substances; and specific highly polymerized compounds.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
This is NOT due to a recent regulatory change but to create a new DB list as a part of CPG project.

Please create a DB list with the following DB List Phrase, for Poisonous Substances regulated by the Special Measures Law Concerning the Prevention of Poisonous Substances from Contaminating Food in Distribution:

Japan. Regulated Poisonous Substances in Food for Distribution (Special Measures Law Concerning the Prevention of Poisonous Substances from Contaminating Food in Distribution, Article 2, Law No. 103 of 26 September 1987, as amended through 13 December 2013)

As per the Law (http://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/topics/importedfoods/guideline/dl/03.pdf), Poisonous Substances are as follows:

  1. Poisonous and Deleterious Substances under the Poisonous and Deleterious Substances Act;
  2. Poisonous and Deleterious Drugs under the Pharmaceutical Affairs Law; and
  3. Pharmaceuticals of which poisonous or deleterious properties are similar to those listed in item (ii) above, excluding those which are listed in item (ii) above.

For item (i) above (Poisonous and Deleterious Substances), please refer to the following six list in our database:

  1. Japan. Deleterious Substances, Cabinet Order (JP_DLA)
  2. Japan. Deleterious Substances, Main Law (JP_DLT)
  3. Japan. Poisonous Substances, Cabinet Order (JP_PSA)
  4. Japan. Poisonous Substances, Main Law (JP_PST)
  5. Japan. Poisonous Substances, Negative List (JP_PSN)
  6. Japan. Deleterious Substances, Negative List (JP_DLN)

For item (ii) above (Poisonous and Deleterious Drugs), the list is currently under preparation by Chemical Daily and expected to be available at the end of September. The list will be uploaded to this WO once it becomes available.

Please create a DB list by combining these seven lists above. Please note that the Law does not specify chemicals under (iii), so please indicate in the DB list that pharmaceuticals with similar poisonous or deleterious properties to those listed in item (ii) above, excluding those listed in item (ii), are also Poisonous Substances under the Law.

Please make sure to capture:

  • Chemical name;
  • CAS RN;
  • Food type;
  • thresholds/cut-off values as indicated in the respective I4C lists;
  • Cut off values; and
  • Exempted chemicals.

Description Of Changes

This is NOT due to a recent regulatory change but to create a new DB list as a part of CPG project.

The list contains Poisonous Substances regulated under the Special Measures Law Concerning the Prevention of Poisonous Substances from Contaminating Food in Distribution. If manufacturers, etc. discover the contaminating, etc. of Poisonous Substances into distributed food pertaining to their business, they must notify the matter to the police or maritime safety station without delay. Also, they are required to cooperate as necessary with investigative organizations so as to facilitate criminal investigations pertaining to the contaminating, etc. of Poisonous Substances into distributed food pertaining to their business.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
This is NOT due to a recent regulatory change but to create a new DB list for Poisonous Drugs and Deleterious Drugs specified in Annex Table 3 under the Law on Securing Quality, Efficacy and Safety of Products Including Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices, as a DB improvement.

Please refer to the source document in English (file name: 20190108薬機法（毒薬・劇薬）) and complete the following steps:

1. create a DB with the following list phrase:

Japan. Poisonous and Deleterious Drugs (Enforcement Rule of the Pharmaceuticals Law, Annex Table 3, MHLW Ordinance No. 1 of 1 February 1961, as amended through 8 January 2019)

2. Poisonous Drugs and Deleterious Drugs (i.e. Enforcement Rule of the Law on Securing Quality, Efficacy and Safety of Products Including Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices, Annex Table 3) are specified in the translated source document. In the DB list, please make sure to capture:

  • Indication as Poisonous Drug or Deleterious Drug;
  • Item No;
  • Chemical name;
  • Exemption and/or threshold values (when applicable); and
  • CAS RN (when available).

* For chemical names in Japanese, please ensure to remove numbering in Japanese or English  (e.g. 一, 二, 三, 四, (1)) inserted before the chemical name. They are generally indicated in bold face. 

NOTE: Please note that this list is added as part of CPG. A food contaminant list (WO 1220) covers all poisonous and deleterious substances and drugs as provided under the following regulations:

  • Poisonous and Deleterious Substances Act; and
  • Pharmaceutical Affairs Law.

Pursuant to the Special Measures Law concerning the Prevention of Poisonous Substances from Contaminating Food in Distribution, any food that contains contaminants as specified above will be subject to additional restrictions, such as reporting requirements. So we put in WO 1220 to create this list.

Based on a discussion between Xiaolu, Phoebe, and Kishore, Phoebe suggested that we should create the Japan. Poisonous and Deleterious Drugs in I4C first, then I4F would use all existing I4C lists for poisonous and deleterious substances and drugs to calculate and create the food contaminant list. 

NOTE:  Per the discussion between Grace and Xiaolu, CRA will look into the translated source document when the assigned member works on this list. This is based on the special request from Chemical Daily, as they cannot guarantee the quality of the translated file due to the complexity of the list. CRA also cannot guarantee the accuracy of the translated file due to lack of language skills, but will verify the translation to identify any apparent translation errors whenever possible. Please see the attached email communication for further details. (2018.10.08)

Description Of Changes

On 11 July 2018, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) announced the removal of 11 substances from the list of Designated Drugs (指定薬物) under the Law on Securing Quality, Efficacy and Safety of Products Including Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices, they are regulated as narcotics after 20 July 2018.

The classification as Designated Drugs will be revoked for the following 11 substances, including their salts:

  1. N-(1-amino-3-methyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)-1-(cyclohexylmethyl)-1H-indazol-3-carboxamide;
  2. N-(1-amino-3-methyl-1-oxobutan-2-yl)-1-pentyl-1H-indazol-3-carboxamide;

In parallel, the amendments to the Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc. were published on the same date to limit use of propiconazole certain fruits such as apricots, cherries and citrus except for specific oranges, with residue limits varying from 0.0006 grams to 0.008 grams per kilogram depending on the type of fruits.

Description Of Changes

This is NOT a recent regulatory change but to create a new DB list as a part of CPG Project.

This list provides the maximum residue limits for agricultural chemicals including pesticide, feed additives and veterinary drugs. The sales, import, distribution, etc. of food products containing the listed agricultural chemicals above the specified maximum residue limits are prohibited. For non-listed agricultural chemicals (i.e. those without maximum residue limits), the uniform limit of 0.01ppm applies, except for those listed in the Pesticide Safe List or Pesticide Negative List.

Description Of Changes

This is NOT a recent regulatory change but to improve the current list to be up to date as a part of CPG Project. By the amendments of 15 March 2012 listed below, the maximum residue limits of radioactive substances were revised:

  • Ministerial Ordinance Partially Revising the Ministerial Ordinance on Milk and Milk Products Concerning Compositional Standards, etc.;
  • Notification on Designating the Radioactive Substances Designated by the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare under the Provisions of Item (I) (1) of the Attached Table 2 of the Ministerial Ordinance on Milk and Milk Products Concerning Compositional Standards, etc.; and
  • Notification on Partial Revision of Specification and Standards for Food, Food Additives, etc.

As a result, more stringent residue limits were set for cesium while the residue limits for other radioactive substances were repealed.

Description Of Changes

On 2 April 2018, Japan's Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW), Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) and Ministry of the Environment (MOE) jointly announced revisions to the list of Monitoring Chemical Substances (MCS) under the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL), removing one substance and adding two substances in the list.

Pursuant to the amendments of 2 April 2018, chlorinated paraffin (C11, Cl=7-12) was removed from the list, as it became a Class I Specified Chemical Substance under CSCL.

In addition, the following two substances are newly designated as MCS:

  • 2,2,4,4,6,6,8,8-Octamethyl-1,3,5,7,2,4,6,8-tetraoxatetrasilocane; and

  • 2,2,4,4,6,6,8,8,10,10,12,12-Dodecamethyl-1,3,5,7,9,11-hexaoxa-2,4,6,8,10,12-hexasilacyclododecane.

The revision became effective on the date of publication.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
Please:

1. Correct the following errors in the database:

(1). Remove the following hazard classes, as they are not adopted in Japan:

GHS000055 Acute toxicity (oral) Hazard category 5
GHS000060 Acute toxicity (dermal) Hazard category 5
GHS000081 Skin corrosion/irritation Hazard category 3
GHS000103 Aspiration hazard Hazard category 2
GHS000137 Acute toxicity (inhalation) Hazard category 5

(2). Correct the symbol for the following hazard class to be Exclamation Mark:

GHS000084 Serious eye damage/eye irritation Hazard category 2B ED-2B Corrosion
Exclamation mark

 

2. Per the discussion between Xiaolu, Sam, Grace, and Sookie on 4 April 2018, Xiaolu reachws out to Beth and Denise to ask for further clarification on how this database is being used by our clients and what kind of impact it would have on our products if we decide to remove the combined H statements. Denise confirmed the following: 3E Generate does not use the labeling elements in the GHS list.  Our system uses logic that is built into the system that looks at the classification and assigns H&P Statements, Signal word, Symbols etc. based on the classification.  It takes into account the combined hazard statements and applies that logic as well all outside of the list.  Any changes to these values would not have an impact on our product.

Based on the information above, CRA and reasearch agreed to remove all combinations of H statements from this database. 

3. Please revise the P statements under this database. Specifially, please remove any P statements that are not identified in table A.1 (表 A.1) through table A. 32 (表 A.32) under Annex A (附属書 A) of the source document (PDF page 17-42):

NOTE: Xiaolu has reached out to Miyo to translate the titles of these tables and the specific hazard categories. Translated titles received and uploaded to this WO on 17 April 2018. 

NOTE: Translation of H and P statements can be found udner the file H_P_Statements_JISZ7253_080312_jpn_rev3-final. Please DO NOT refer to the hazard classes provided under column D and E that are associated with the combined H statements. They are wrong assignments of hazard classes to combined H statements, which is what caused the issue of repetitive H statements being addressed under this WO. 

Thank you.

Description Of Changes

Revision of hazard classes and H statements.

Japan. Class I Specified Chemical Substances (as amended through 21 February 2018);

2. do a full proof of the existing database against the excel sheet (titled '20180221化審法特定化学物質re180417') and add what is currently missing and delete what is not listed. Please make sure to capture:

- Chemical name in English/Japanese;

Description Of Changes

On 21 February 2018, Japan’s Prime Minister and competent ministries (i.e. Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI), Ministry of the Environment (MOE) and Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW)) jointly published amendments to the Cabinet Order under the Chemical Substances Control Law (CSCL).

As a result, the following two substances were designated as Class I Specified Chemical Substances as of 1 April 2018, being subject to restrictions/prohibition for manufacture, import and use:

-          Polychlorinated linear-chain paraffin, limited to those that have 10 to 13 in the number of carbons and whose chlorine content is over 48% in the total weight; and

-          1, 1’-oxybis (2, 3, 4, 5, 6-pentabromobenzene; alias, decabromodiphenyl ether).

Furthermore, there are a lot of CAS#s that wasn't previously captured or deleted from this DB list. Hence, the current DB list needs a full proof to add what is currently missing and delete what is not listed.

- Preparations with concentrations at or below 0.0082% (i.e. preparations<=0.0082%) are Deleterious Substances;

-  Preparations in the container with a capacity of 1 liter or less and content of 0.000082% or less are excluded.

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
Please note this WO contains changes due to:

  • Modifications to address discrepancies from WO 399 which was supposed to replace the DB to the latest version; and
  • Amendments of 30 November 2017.

Please change DB List Phrase to:

Japan. Food Additives Manufacturing Standard (MHLW Notice No. 370, 28 December 1959, as amended through 30 November 2017)

Please refer to the Word (“FoodAdditiveManufacturingStandards_Comparison_MI2”) and implement the following actions, referring to the structure of the current database for further details on the type of information to be captured: Please note that there are two types of changes contained in this file:

  • information highlighted in yellow is the revisions introduced under the update issue on 30 Nov. 2017
  • information indicated with track changes is the difference between the most updated source document and the source document for WO 399, other than the ones contained in the Nov. 30 update.

To fix the discrepancies between the most updated source document and source document for WO 399, please:

1. Please extract necessary information on the prohibition and restrictions imposed on the manufacture of food additives as provided under Part 2 and 5 of the section "Additive in General."

2. Please make sure to capture the information on restrictions on the use of additives in certain product types as provided below Part 5 of the section "Additives in General":

- Change in salt water; and

-  Removal of the following in Use Category throughout the DB list.

- Tamarind Seed Gum;

- Garlic Extract;

- Pepper Extract; and

- Wasabi Extract.

For the update issued on 30 Nov, 2017, please:

1. Extract necessary information on the prohibition and restrictions imposed on the manufacture of food additives as provided under Part 4 of the section "Additive in General."

2. Please make sure to capture the information on restrictions on the use of additives in certain product types as provided below Part 5 of the section "Additives in General" as below:

    (1) Addition of talc; and

    (2) Change chemical name in the DB list from Ethyl methyl ketone to 2-Butanone.

Description Of Changes

The amendments of 30 November 2017 brought the following changes:

  • Establishment of provisions on strains of microorganism for manufacture of enzymes using microorganism (Item 4 in the Food Additive Manufacturing Standard);
  • Addition of a provision to require use of asbestos-free raw materials for talc (Paragraph on 'Talc' in the Food Additive Manufacturing Standard); and
  • Change of the chemical name from Ethyl methyl ketone to 2-Butanone.

The actual changes are highlighted in red in the Word file ("食品添加物 - 食品添加物製造基準_manufacturing_FFCR_eng_With Highlight_MI").

The amended Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc. is accessible online in Japanese at the MHLW website. (http://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000186592.html)
SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) released on 30 November 2017 amendments to the Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc. (食品、添加物等の規格基準) under the Food Sanitation Law. The amendments took effect upon publication while a one-year transitional period is granted to affected businesses.

The amendments of 30 November 2017 are related to food additives including the following:

  • Revision of and addition to certain general test procedures;
  • Addition and removal of test reagent and improvement in the test reagent list (e.g. test reagent names changed to be consistent with the Japan Industrial standards, and CAS numbers are added);
  • Establishment of compositional standards for 62 enzymes and 27 others (e.g. annatto coloring, welan gum, gamma-oryzanol);
  • Revision to certain purity tests under the compositional standards;
  • Establishment of provisions on strains of microorganism for manufacture of enzymes using microorganism;
  • Addition of a provision to require use of asbestos-free raw materials for talc; and
  • Change of the chemical name from Ethyl methyl ketone to 2-Butanone.

The last three bullets in bold with underlines are amendments related to this DB (i.e. Food Additives Manufacturing Standard)

The amended Specifications and Standards for Food and Food Additives, etc. is accessible online in Japanese at the MHLW website. (http://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000186592.html)

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.General Instructions:
Please:

- Revise DB List Phrase to:

Japan. ISHL Hazardous Substances for Annual Worker Exposure Reporting (MHLW Public Notice No. 25 of 16 February 2006, as amended through 27 December 2017);

- Refer to the attached Excel (Title: ISHL Hazardous Substances for Annual Reporting_2018) and add three substances in red. Please make sure to capture all the inforamtion in the table.

Description Of Changes

On 27 December 2017, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) published a list of hazardous substances subject to an annual reporting obligation under the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL).

The following substances, including preparations containing them in the concentrations below, are listed:  

  • Tetrahydrofuran (CAS RN: 109-99-9) (0.1% or more by weight);
  • 2,4,6-Trichlorophenol (CAS RN: 88-06-2) (0.1% or more by weight); and
  • Furfuryl alcohol (CAS RN: 98-00-0) (1% or more by weight).

     

    Companies manufacturing or handling these substances, including preparations containing them, are required to submit an annual report to the Head of Labor Standards Supervision Office. The requirement applies when meeting all the following conditions:

    - Manufacture or handling takes place from 1 January 2018 to 31 December 2018;

    - Manufactured or handled quantity is 500 kilograms or more; and

    - There is a risk of worker exposure to gases, steams or dusts of the substances at workplaces.

     

The annual report will have to be submitted between 1 January 2019 to 31 December 2019.

Please:

1. Revise the DB List Phrase to:

Japan. ISHL Mutagens, Existing Chemicals (Ministry of Labor Notice, May 17, 1993, as amended through 21 November 2017);

2. Refer to the attached Excel (Tab: '安変新') and add the following information of eight chemical substances in yellow to the database:

- Chemical name in English/Japanese;

- CAS RNs;

- Japan ENCS Number in Row J (i.e. Data_10); and

- Threshold concentration in Row T (i.e. Data_20).

3. Revise the explanation on concentration limits in the database as below since the values indicated are exclusive:

From: Japan. Chemical is subject to this regulation if present at more than or equal to this wt%

To: Japan. Chemical is subject to this regulation if present at more than this wt%

 

Description Of Changes

On 21 November 2017, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) announced designation of 38 chemical substances as mutagens from the lists of existing and new chemical substances under the Industrial Safety and Health Law. Manufacture and handling of these mutagens are subject to health and safety measures at workplaces.

The following six chemical substance from the list of existing chemical substances are designated as mutagens:

  • Bis(4-nitrophenyl) ether (CAS RN: 101-63-3);
  • Naphthalene-1,8-diyldiamine (CAS RN: 479-27-6);
  • Selenium dioxide (CAS RN: 7446-08-4);
  • 4-(Trifluoromethyl)aniline (CAS RN: 455-14-1);
  • 4-Amino-3-methylphenol (CAS RN: 2835-99-6); and
  • 1,2-dihydroxy-9,10-anthraquinone (CAS RN: 72-48-0).

     

    Also, 32 chemical substances from the list of new chemical substances are designated as mutagens. Examples are as follows:

  • Mixture of ethyl glyoxylate polymer and toluene (CAS RN: Not available);
  • 2-chloro-2'-(2-fluorobenzoyl)-N-methyl-4'-nitroacetanilide (CAS RN: Not available);
  • 1-{4-[2-(2,4-diaminophenoxy) ethoxy]phenyl}-2-hydroxy-2-methylpropan-1-one  (CAS RN: Not available);
  • 1-{4-[2-(2,4-dinitrophenoxy) ethoxy]phenyl}-2-hydroxy-2-methylpropan-1-one  (CAS RN: Not available); and
  • 3,4-dibromobutane-2-one (CAS RN: Not available).

Please:

- Revise DB Phrase to:

Japan. Industrial Safety& Health Law (ISHL) Inventory (as amended through 27 September 2017)

- Open the attached Excel file (Tab: 20170927ISHA-new) and add the listed chemical substances to the DB. Please make sure to capture the following:

 1. Chemical name in English/Japanese;

 2. CAS RNs;

 3. Japanese ISHL number ('整理番号' in Row D).

 

Description Of Changes

On 27 September 2017, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) published names of new chemical substances under the Industrial Safety and Health Law (ISHL).  

The new chemical substances are those that were notified to the Minister of Health, Labor and Welfare with hazard assessment results and other relevant information prior to their manufacture or import. As a result of the publication of 26 September 2017, they have now become existing chemical substances under ISHL. The MHLW usually publishes the list of notified new chemical substances on a quarterly basis in March, June, September and December.

Please refer to the attached Excel and create a chemical list containing the following information:

- English name/Japanese name;

- CAS RN;

- Code No.;

- Threshold concentration values (Row E);

- Year for manufacture/handling (Row G);

- Reporting period (Row H);

- Publication date; and

- Effective date.

 

Description Of Changes

This database is newly created as per client's request.

This is a list of hazardous chemical substances of which manufacture or handling is subject to an annual reporting on worker exposure. Companies manufacturing or handling the listed substances, including mixtures containing them in specific concentrations, are required to submit an annual report to the Head of Labor Standards Supervision Office. The requirement applies when meeting all the following conditions:
- manufacture or handling takes place from 1 January to 31 December of the target year;
- manufactured or handled quantity is 500 kilograms or more; and
- there is a risk of worker exposure to gases, steams or dusts of the listed substances at workplaces.

The report must be submitted between 1 January and 31 March of the following year. The list is revised every year, replacing chemicals subject to the requirement.

On 14 June 2017, Japan’s Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare (MHLW) announced the addition of two substances and the removal of five substances from the list of Deleterious Substances as stipulated in the Poisonous & Deleterious Substances Designation Order. In addition, one substance was removed from the Poisonous Substances list. The removal of the six substances took effect upon the announcement on 14 June 2017, while the addition of the two substances became effective on 1 July 2017, with transitional periods for certain requirements.

The amendment requires only a change in DB list phrase. No update in the list itself is necessary.

Dear Science Data Team,

Please,

1) update the date of the DB (QSNAB82) to 21 June 2018

2) delete the content of Item (1) [cannabis substances], as indicated in paragraph 204 (1) (see page 134).

3) Please add the content from paragraph 204 (2): "Synthetic cannabinoid receptor type 1 agonists, their salts, derivatives, isomers, and salts of derivatives and isomers — with the exception of any substance that is identical to any phytocannabinoid and with the exception of ((3S)-2,3-dihydro-5-methyl-3-(4morpholinylmethyl)pyrrolo[1,2,3-de]-1,4benzoxazin-6-yl)-1-naphthalenyl-methanone (WIN 55,212-3) and its salts — including those that fall within the following core chemical structure classes:"

Note: the last phrase "…including those that fall within the following core chemical classes:" is then followed by existing content of Item (2) – I think that there is no change in those items.

Please see attached documents: 1) Act of 2018, 2) current content of Schedule II taken from the official regulatory source.

4) Update the date of the DB (QSNAB85) to 31 August 2022.

5) This database should not have content as that is what currently shows in Schedule V taken from the official regulatory source. Therefore, I recommend eliminating all of the substances except the one in Order from 31 August 2022 and include a note that says, "Substance removed by Order Amending Schedule V to the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, SOR/2022-185 (Canada Gazette, 31 August 2022)".

SELECT DISTINCT\r\n WO.WOId AS [Work.Regulatory Background:
1) Canada in the First Session, Forty-second Parliament, 64-65-66-67 Elizabeth II, 2015-2016-2017-2018 STATUTES OF CANADA 2018 CHAPTER 16 on 21 June 2018 enacted "An Act respecting cannabis and to amend the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, the Criminal Code and other Acts".

This Act includes in paragraph 204 that repeals Item 1 in Schedule II and replaces a portion of Item 2. This WO captures that change.

2) Canada issues Order Amending Schedule V to the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (SOR/2022-185, Gazette, 31 August 2022).
